pwn: ti kapi kipaqaljay ta dokiosi, sa qivo no tjaivililj tjara kemaco ta niaken a nemanga, masalo tjanomon ka tjaisangas pokaoi a pasedjam ta nemanga tja noaken.
english: Kapi apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.

pwn: a ko kama na i qinaljan a cinonan.
english: My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

pwn: ka qaqonoan na ken, ti kama kati djisan no itoa qezemezemetj vaik a ljesasaw, kemaco ta tjakit kata kowang.
english: When I was little, my dad and uncle would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

pwn: nomaljia, mangetjez tiamadjo a na kemaco ta djinameq a sacemel.
english: At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

pwn: nocoayanga vavoy, nocoayanga lava, noaya izoa padjavatan ota.
english: Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

pwn: aza sacemel qaloqaloten niamadjo i siljitaladj toa qinaljan a paljing, pasleva toa sikataqaljan.
english: They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

pwn: sakamaya ro qemevaw a ken tja kama, sa kiciol a qemaljop kati kama.
english: Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

pwn: aya ti kama no meqaca son, ko so kacoaw anga.
english: Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

pwn: a i qinaljan a oqaljaqaljay macaqo a podringay djemekep ta sacemel, tiamadjo saigo cokolo ta veceqel a dringay kata siqezetjan toa qaciljay a dringay.
english: The men of the tribe also trap their prey, making lasso traps and rock traps.

pwn: a ko kama saigo a cokolo ta veceqel a dringay, aya ti kama, aico oli sidringay ta padjavatan, tja kigaljoing a ljemengljeng za na sacemel a djekap, za dringay tja pizoaing ta na sacemel vinaikan a djaljan.
english: My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

pwn: olja dikilo a kilimo kata ramaljeng maciol a qemaljop, no ljemita qadaw kicaqoan a cokolo ta dringay, aza o dringay oli palamo anga paqolid a maqati djemameq toa sacemel.
english: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

pwn: ti ka paconan na ken qivo tjanoaken, no tjaivililj tjara masan saigoan son a cinonan.
english: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

pwn: toco meqacanga ken, ko sevaljeng a o panaq kata vakela, kiciol ta ko kama vaik a qemaljop.
english: Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

pwn: ka sema qinaljan, aza nia djinameq a sacemel oli pasleva toa sikataqaljan.
english: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

pwn: aya ti kama, masalo aravac tana qemati a sinipagaogaw. pavayan itjen to liaw ta sacemel a mangoaqan.
english: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.

pwn: ta kadjaman gemaljo aken a ma tatakisian.
english: I was late for school this morning.

pwn: tazoa vayke sema tatakesiyan, ini paqenedjanga aken a masi qabang.
english: When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.

pwn: ini ken na kemaco ta nanemangao.
english: I didn't bring anything with me.

pwn: a kitolotolo tazoa, maciyol a pacon ta kadop aken kata dokiwsi.
english: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

pwn: a semekiseking tazoa, pasedjaman aken ta inpic kata sisomasomang na dokiwsi.
english: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

pwn: kakivoin aken na sinsi, "no djavililj gacaljoanga kilimo, maya gemalj anga!"
english: The teacher told me, "Wake up earlier next time and don't be late again!"
My good friend's name is kadrw, and he is also an Paiwan child.

pwn: na maciyol a men a kisopo i kaalowan.
english: We study together in the kaaluwan tribe.

pwn: djaloljes amen a maciyol kilangda ta djawcikel a milimilimgan na lamaljeng, macaqo amen qivo ta pinaywanan.
english: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Paiwan proficiently.

pwn: ljavavaw aken sa mekaca, ti kadrw maliljay sa kedrikedri.
english: I am tall and overweight, while kadrw is short and thin.

pwn: lo talivakan ti kadraw, djengelay a men djay madjo a mapoljat.
english: kadrw is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

pwn: ongdokay na i gako to sa qadaw, maljeliyav a kamoko sinipa malalomaljan na gako.
english: Today was the school's sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

pwn: izoa malalakac ta calis, sema kola a benolo, mekelj, dremaiyan, katoa penana.
english: There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.
I participated in the running competition.

pwn: tazoa a mekelj aken, sekolilj aken, pedjamo to liyav a congal.
english: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

pwn: ljakoa migacalj aken, sa pazolonge a mekelj a pasasangas.
english: But I stood up and continued running forward.

pwn: maleva cawcaw anga a djemaljon aken.
english: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

pwn: noavan na ini a malap ta sangasangasa. ljaqoa maleva ken alavac. ayatoa na paodeze anga ken toa kinimalalomaljan.
english: Although I didn't get first place, I'm glad because I completed the race.

pwn: na paljilji ta ko ama aken ati kama ta tiyiv.
english: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

pwn: na mapasa'edjo a kola ni ama.
djmaljan amen ni madjona, makapalaq to ita beleng a na omaq a 'aljiv.
english: He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

pwn: a ljemengongo ta 'aljiv na omaq ti madjo, makelo anga kemasi ta omaq na 'aljiv.
english: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

pwn: na kemaco ti kama ta na gong a vodjolj 'ata saviki sipavay djay ama.
english: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

pwn: i 'omaan a mazazepezep a ken ati ama.liyav a milimilinga sini djawcikel ni madjo.
english: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

pwn: a mori vayika anga ken, zemengel ti ama to mekacanga ken, mapavalit to djasawqaljay to.
english: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

pwn: 'evo ken, "no mengowa anga so kola ama, keljoanga ta nia omaq kivangavang no djayvililj to."
english: I said, "When your foot gets better, come to our house next time and visit us."

pwn: i ta drosa kozolj sa drosa polo sa drosa cavilj, na kaygi anga a asiho a pita mibongsiw na kacalisiyan ta ngadan makayanga pasa ita ngadan noa kinacalisianan.
english: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

pwn: na homong aken ta coacoayanga kilevoci pasa ta siho a pita mibosow pizowanan ta "pasa ita ngadan na kinacalisian " i qinalja a maacovocovong. lja savan ti camaq.
english: I interviewed camaq, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

pwn: toco a sisekesekez a qadaw na pinedjan aken ati madjo to mazowa ta omaq nimadj a homong.
english: We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

pwn: a homong tazow, pasemalaven aken ni madjo to pinakasinoan a ngadan ni madjo, otanga kacoin aken a pakeljang ta tacekeljan ni madjo, ta qinaljan ni madjo.
english: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

pwn: ko kivadaan ti madjo a komaya ki temezeng pasopavalit ta ngadan, nakoya sipavecikana a kakodanan ta sicoayan.
english: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn't the old registration method sufficient?

pwn: kakivoin aken ni madjo, ayatoa na sipavecikan ta ciniwkokan ini a mapacengceng a pkeljangn ta ngadan ni madjo, azoma cawcaw maytoco anan a qivo "ca sinsi" ot manasika sidjawljan to paseliyaw toa penapedjeli.
english: He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him "Cha Xian Sheng," which resulted in many jokes being made.

pwn: lja savan ti camaq kivo, "a tja kaolidan a ngadan no kinakacalisiyan a sivecikan ta ngadan mavan na djaljemedjem, aza ko ngadan sikaqeljangan to anema men no zokan, ljanema men a djomaan, nidjen a kinapatalevanan i kacawan. pozangalan to makaya maljeliav azokan a cawcaw kipakim ta so kiningadangan."
english: camaq kivu said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

pwn: ta tiyav ti aken kati vovo avavayan vayke a ma icipa ta papaveliyanan, na kemaco ti vovo avavayan ta liyav a namakakayzoazoa a sinitalem a lacing, otanga sikipoalan ta na kacalisiyan a kakanen sipakan toa mapoljat.
english: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

pwn: na djengelay a mapoljat ta ni vovo a papaveliyanan, a kamangolj ata loni maljeleav a cawcaw veneli, maljeleav a cawcaw mangedjez a keman ta sinanljaceng ni madjo.
english: Everyone loved my grandmother's stall. Many people bought the chilis and African eggplants, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

pwn: sangowa alavac a kines ni madjo a lokoce kata djoadjoay a kinsa. izoanan a siljato ta vavoy pinasazoan ta daykong kata tjana, aza saloman masiljodje ta maljeliyav a kaljakalja. mangdjez a mapoljat sa madjoljol ita niamen a papaveliyan.
english: The ferns and sticky rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

pwn: no kemesakesa ta nemanga ti vovo, i djoljival aken a djemawdjaolj ta kaljakalja. i djoljival a ken a mezangal a djemawdjaw, "a ljaceng savtde a niya sinitalem, ini a pinizoanan ta kahiliyoan a si vevoan, veliyo a kilalimo lja!"
english: While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, \The vegetables are self-grown

pwn: a nia nemanga ma veli a kilimo, kivota vovo, "masa izowa son a paqeljing."
english: Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, "It's all thanks to your help."

pwn: aicoa a kiniposengsenganan, izoa ko kinitoloan paka ta kacalisiyan a zazomok katowa sikeljangan ta kakanen a kakodan, mayanga izoa nga kinakeljangan ta kiposngesngan ita papavelian aza loljayan.
english: Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

pwn: paconan ti vovo djengelay alavaca toa semicoacoayan a kakanen, djevalongan aken ta samamaljian a acianan atowa pozangalan.
english: Seeing my grandmother's passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.

pwn: pitjo a zikangan a ko sisagakkoan no kadjamadjaman.
english: I arrived at school at seven today.

pwn: kitoloi anga, semaomaqan a sinsi, qivo a pancang a mayatoco, "gacalji! kicongali!"
english: It's time for class, the teacher walked into the classroom, and the monitor said: "Stand up! Salute!"

pwn: no kitolotolo amen, toloan amen ni sinsi toa sopo na kinacalisiyanan.
english: In class, the teacher taught us the paiwan language of numbers.

pwn: kitjavililj amen a kitolo tjai sinsi, saka men a semenasenay anga toa senay noa semopo.
english: We followed the teacher to read, we sang the number song.

pwn: liyav anga ko kinacaqo a penaiwanan a kai.
english: I have learned many paiwan languages.

pwn: djemedje aken a sema gakko, djemedje aken a kitolo toa pinaiwanan, ori ko sipaladenga tjai kina.
english: I go to school every day, I learn the paiwan language every day, and I want to tell my mother.

pwn: ti Koljelje a ngadan na ko kama.
ti Saoniyaw a ngadan na ko kina.
tapoloq anga a ko cavilj toco.
izoa za ko kaka a oqaljay a tjavolong, ti Kapi a ngadan, tapoloq anga saka ita a cavilj nimadjo.
english: I have a brother, his name is Kapi, he is 11 years old.
We study in the same school.
Both my brother and I like to sing.

pwn: tjengelay aken a emave'av/ljemangoy, no kaljapolavayan, vaik amen a emave'av/ljemangoy a tacekeljan.
english: I like swimming. During the holidays, our whole family go swimming together.

pwn: tjengelay aken a kipoqali, maqati amen a maciyociyor a semenay a emave'av.
english: I love meeting new people, we can sing and swim together.
There are five people in our family.
There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

pwn: izoa ti kama/ama, ti kina/ina tiaken, katoa ko kaka a tjavolong a oqaljay katoa tjavolong a vavayan, namatevetevelj amen a tacekeljan.
english: I live with my father, mother, brother and sister.

pwn: qacaqaca ti kama, kisaco a ko kama.
english: My father is tall and he is a policeman.

pwn: riljariljay ti kina, koisang a ko kina.
english: My mother is thin and my mom is a doctor.

pwn: qivoyivo ti kama toa penaiyoanan i tjomaq tjanoamen.
english: My father speaks the paiwan language with us at home.

pwn: no kaljapolavayan cemikel amen a sema qinaljan.
english: We will all go back to the tribe during the summer vacation.

pwn: vaik aken katoa mareka ko kaka a tjavavolongan a djemekep toa kiav.
english: My brothers and sisters and I will catch frogs together.

pwn: tjengelay aken aravac toa mareka ko sikatacemekeljan.
english: I like our family very much.

pwn: vaik amen ati kina a kivangavang toco a qadav.
english: I went out with my mother today.

pwn: namaljengoaq a kalevelevan no moqadadav, inika ljemaljaqel inika zemolezol, sarengoaq ca vali.
english: The sky is blue during the day, the weather is neither cold nor hot, and the wind is cool.

pwn: kemakan amen ta minpao i cemecemel i azatjan, ipaqadav amen, semeljec aravac.
english: We ate bread on the grass, the sun was shining on us, and it was very warm.
In the afternoon, the sky turned red.

pwn: ko kivadaqan ti kina, akoazoa meqodjilj co a kalevelevan?
english: I asked my mother why the sky is red.

pwn: qivo ti kina, panema ta ori ozazanga a vali aya.
english: Mom said, maybe the typhoon is coming.

pwn: no qazemezemetj neka zoa kelebav i kalevelevan, tjevota anga a vitjoqan.
english: There were no clouds in the sky at night, and the stars came out.

pwn: tjomatjomaq amen i djalan, kisaljinga aken ta vitjoqan.
english: On the way home, I made a wish with the stars

pwn: saljinga ken toa inika mangtjez a vali, pasa vaivaik anan aken a kivangavang aya ken.
english: I hope the typhoon doesn't come, I still want to go out to play again.

pwn: i ljaqediqedi toa nia omaq a ko gakko, djemedje aken a djemavac a sema gakko, sa 'o djavac ota a tjomaq.
english: My school is next to our house, I walk to school every day, and I also walk home.

pwn: inika tjaljiqacaqaca a nia gakko, inika tjorovo a mareka vencik, namakakeljakeljang amen a masantalj.
english: Our school is not big, there are not many students, everyone knows each other.

pwn: namatevetevelj amen i vava'asan, maciyociyor amen a seman mali, sa'a matjatjaoci'eci'el amen ota.
english: All the children will gather in the playground, play ball and chat together.

pwn: kisaseljang tjanoamen a nia sinsi a kivangavang ota, namaya toa tacemekeljan amen i gakko.
english: The teachers also play with us, the school is one big family.

pwn: ljemita to qadav a semoasoap amen, maljiyan toa namaparimasodj aravac a nia kakitoloan.
english: We have to clean every day, and everyone has to clean the classroom.

pwn: izoa vaik a semisic toa qezong, izoa vaik a semoap ta zaqetja.
english: Some people clean the windows, some sweep the floor.

pwn: nia soapen anan a penalingoljan a nia gakko, mapangapangalj amen toa sengsengan, namapalimasodj a ljemita to qadav a nia gakko.
english: We will also clean every corner of the school. Everyone works together, and the school is very clean every day.

pwn: navaik aken a sema qinaljan a kivala tjaivovo tatiav.
english: Yesterday, I went to visit my grandpa in the tribe.

pwn: coacoay anga men a inika mecevocevong, sengelit anga aken tjaimadjo.
english: We haven't seen each other for a long time and I miss him a lot.

pwn: tapaconan aken ni vovo, pakanan aken toa soika, patekelan aken toa otja.
english: As soon as grandpa saw me, he invited me to eat watermelon and drink tea.

pwn: qaljemaqem aravac a sinitalem ni vovo a soika, sangoaq angata.
english: The watermelon grown by grandpa is very sweet and really delicious.

pwn: tjengelay aken a temekel toa otja ni vovo ota, sangoaq aravac.
english: I also like grandpa's tea, it's tasted good too.

pwn: vecekadan no qadav, kemesa amen kati vovo toa nia cengelj.
english: At noon, I cooked lunch with my grandma.

pwn: nakemesa anga ti vovo toa masanliyaliav a kinsa, izoa ciqav, izoa koka, izoa tjingkoy, izoa kacikacing/dingding.
english: Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

pwn: ta makakincengelj amen, vaik amen a sema poljacengan a ki ljaceng.
english: After lunch, we went to the vegetable garden to pick vegetables.

pwn: sikalap aken ni vovo toa liav a vorati, a vasa katoa niniko, kaco-o a tjomaq aya.
english: Grandma brought me a lot of sweet potatoes, taro and buckwheat, and asked me to take them home.

pwn: ko kiposaoan tiamadjo, sa kinamangtjez anan no tjaivililj a kivala tjanomon ko ayain.
english: I said goodbye to them and said I'd see them next time.

pwn: toco a qadav kacoin amen ni sinsi a sema toa zaziljavan toa qemoziqozip, kipacomali amen a veneli toa kipo i paljing.
english: Today the teacher took us to the zoo, and we lined up at the gate to buy tickets.

pwn: ta tedep amen i poqemoziqozipan, qivo ti sinsi, "aico a i qayav mareka qayaqayam, azoa i vililj mareka qatjovi, ziljavo a masantalj."
english: After entering the zoo, the teacher said, There are birds in the front and snakes in the back

pwn: marekotj aken ta qatjovi, manasika inika navaik a pacon toa mareka qatjovi.
english: I'm afraid of snakes, so I don't look at snakes.

pwn: pacon aken toa liav a qayaqayam, minlayalayap i vavav toa kasiv, izoa za ljeqo i taladje toa kasiv a nataqed ota.
english: I saw a lot of birds flying around in the trees and saw owls sleeping in tree hollows.

pwn: izoa za zo, onma katoa likoljav i poqemoziqozipan, inika napavala pacon toca mareka qemoziqozip, maleva aken angata toa ko pinaconan toco a qadav.
english: There are elephants, horses and tigers in the zoo. I have never seen these animals before. I was really happy to see them today.

pwn: napasasing aken a pakaliav, sa ko sipapacon tjai kama kati kina.
english: I took a lot of pictures and showed them to my parents.

pwn: sa'a no tjaivililj tjara kinakiciyor tjai kama kati kina a sema maza.
english: Next time I will come with my parents.

pwn: toco a polavay, vaik a ken katoa ko kaka a tjavolong a vavayan a sema akav a kivala tjai kama i Drona.
english: This holiday, my sister and I went to Taitung to visit my uncle.

pwn: maka kisiya amen a kemasi Taihoko a sema Akav.
english: We took the train from Taipei to Taitung.

pwn: djemaljom amen i Akav, na onting toa haiya ti kama i Drona a kicacevong tjanoamen.
english: When we arrived in Taitung, my uncle drove to the station to pick us up.

pwn: inika cemadja a omaq ni kama i Drona toa tisaba, inika coway i djalan djemaljon anga.
english: The station is not far from my uncle's house, and it's just a short drive away.

pwn: izoa za i djemet toa omaq a tjaljiqacaqaca a qoma ni kama i Drona, vaik amen a semazoa a makapalidring.
english: There is a big ranch near my uncle's house, and we rode bicycles to the ranch together.

pwn: i toa qoma, kacoin amen ni kama i Drona a pakan toa sizi katoa gong.
english: In the ranch, my uncle Druna took us to feed the sheep and ride horses.

pwn: ta masolem, kacoin amen a sema lizok a keman toa kinsa.
english: In the evening, we went to the city to have dinner together.

pwn: liav aravac a pacacikecikel a sidosiya/haiya i kadjalanan, manasika maka otobai amen a sema zoa.
english: There are a lot of cars in the city, so we go there by motorcycle.

pwn: ta ori vavaik anga men izoa, mano cinekav anga nia otobay, saka nia maka baso anga sakamay.
english: When we were about to leave, we found that the motorcycle had been stolen, so we had to leave by bus.

pwn: nacemikel anga men a sema Taihoko toco, inika ken a kemeljang toi djinomak anga a otobay ni kama i Drona.
english: Now that we are back in Taipei, I don't know if my uncle's motorcycle has been found.

pwn: i Akav a nia omaq ta kakedriyan anan aken, ta sema gakko anga ken, patjavat amen a sema Taoyon, saka izoazoa angamen i lizok a kikavaljot a patjetoco.
english: When we were young, our family lived in Donghe. After I started school, we moved to Taoyuan and have been living in the city ever since.

pwn: makalap anga aken toa taigakko, sa ko kitolo toazoz masanitalj a patjara no kacalisian a kakodakodan a tolo, avanazoa kemeljang aken toa napenakaizoazoa a tja kakodan a kacalisian i Taiwan.
english: After I went to college, I took a course on aboriginal culture and learned that the aboriginal people in Taiwan have various and rich cultures.

pwn: manasika, toco a cavilj a polavay toa zolezolan, vaik aken katoa ko kaka a tjavolong a oqaljay a sema qinaljan a kivadaq toa ramaljemaljeng, pasa kikeljang amen toa nitjen a kakodakodan.
english: So this summer, my brother and I went back to our tribe to visit the elderly, hoping to understand the culture of our own ethnic group.

pwn: aloangapoloq a cavilj ni vovo, ljakoa no tja paconan nasa'edriyan anan sakamaya.
english: The old man is already eighty years old, but he still looks like a middle-aged man.

pwn: ko kivadaqan timadjo to anemanema kinacaqo a kai, taoliq aravac a qivo toa penayoanan, macaqo a dremipongan, a dremekaiyan katoa penairangan ota.
english: I asked him which languages he knew, and he was fluent in Saisiyat, as well as Atayal, Hakka and Japanese.

pwn: ta makakivadaq anga ken tjaimadjo, djaljepan ta kakedrian anan timadjo, na kitolo toa dremipongan, azoa cekelj se drekai zoko, saka pizoa toa sengsengan nimadjo nasekeljang toa tjorovo a pairang, manasika liav a kinacaqo a kai nimadjo.
english: I asked him to find out that he learned Japanese when he was a child, his wife is an Atayal, and he knows many Hakkas at work, so he can speak so many languages.

pwn: itoa nia kinaqepoan, liav aravac a sitjaocikecikel toa patjara semicoacoayan a caqoan noa qemaljop.
english: During our interview, the old man talked about a lot of traditional knowledge about hunting.

pwn: ljai inika men a sepoalalang, ljakoa nia linoing a paka toa dingwa, maqati a nia omaljen anan a kiladenga.
english: Although we could't fully understand it, we could record it on our cell phones and listen to it more.

pwn: ta kakedrian anan aken, inika ken a nakemeljang toa tja kakodan a paiwan, nasemiaq to kacalisian aken pai.
english: When I was young, I didn't understand the culture of my ethnic group, and I was a little embarrassed that I was an aborigine.

pwn: no tjaliav a ko kinljangan, tja ljemaoi to Paiwan zoko aken, napakisomalji, sedjaljep to ko sikipasokoda ota.
english: The more I know, the more I feel that being a Saisiyat is unique and something to be proud of.

pwn: toco a masolesolem a qadav, ori tjomaq a ko kaka a tjaljaljak a oqaljay.
english: My younger brother is going home this evening.

pwn: vaik aken katoa ko vovo a sema siyobai a veneli ta koka, padjolo ta sipakaiv toa ko kaka a tjaljaljak a oqaljay.
english: My grandma and I went to the market to buy chickens and prepared a delicious dinner for my younger brother.

pwn: cemalivat amen itoa paveliveli ta ljaceng, liav aravac a za namapakaizoazoa a nasasangoaq a ljaceng.
english: We passed the vegetable stand, which had a lot of fresh green vegetables.

pwn: naveneli amen toa kabola, qaqilj katoa taicav.
english: We bought chinese cabbage, yams and carrots.

pwn: maitoco aza paveliveli ta kodamono a taoki, "qaljemaqem aravac ca o pangodralj katoa kotjis. pay veliyo to kedri!"
english: The owner of the nearby fruit stand said: "My pineapples and peaches are very sweet. Buy some!"

pwn: saka nia veli anga ta pangodralj katoa kotjis.
cemalivat amen toa povotjoljan, qivo a taoki, "anema no veliin? paconi co a o koka kakodralan saka sasangoaq aravac, no ita tjeloaiday a avelian."
english: We passed the meat stall, and the boss said, "What do you want to buy? Today's chickens are big and fat, and one is 300 NTD."

pwn: pazangal co aya ti vovo, saka kivadaq ta taoki toi maqati a papemadjoloin.
english: Grandma thought it was too expensive and asked the boss if it could be cheaper.

pwn: ljakoa qivo a taoki, madjolo anga co, inika maqati anga tja kilovadan aya.
english: But the boss said that it is already very cheap and cannot be reduced any further.

pwn: maitoco aza kiljaqediqedi a taoki a qivo, ido veliyo ta ko ciqav, kakodralan sa mamadjoloan.
english: The boss next door said, come and buy my fish, my fish is big and cheap.

pwn: ta vililjanga naveneli anga men ta koka ta ciqaw, saka nia vaik anga a tjomaq a kemesa toa tahandayan a djamay.
english: In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.

pwn: coai amen a kiljaljavaljav, masolem anga.
english: After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

pwn: mano pakadingowa a ko kaka a tjaljaljak a oqaljay, inika maqati anga a polavai aya i posivitayan, ori pinotjaivililj anga ko sisatjomaqan aya.
english: The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn't take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

pwn: na kemesa anga itjen a pakaliav aya ti vovo, pai tja kanavanga sakamaya a masantalj!
english: Grandma said that she has cooked so much, so let's eat together!

pwn: nia djaoljen anga sakamaya a nia kaka katoa nia qali, saka nia atevetevelj a kaiv.
english: We invited friends and family to have a great dinner together.

pwn: izoa za ko salasaladj a ti Uljelje, ro draodrav a kemaco toa nemanga nimadjo.
english: I have a classmate named Uljelje, he often forgets to bring things.

pwn: no kitolotolo amen, kisedjam timadjo toa salasaladj ta inpic, siqoliqolip katoa vaveikan a laqolj/zakitjo.
english: During class, he borrowed pencils, erasers or notebooks from his classmates.

pwn: poita, podrosa, potjelo, nia pasedjam sakamaya timadja.
english: Once, twice, three times, everyone would lend him something.

pwn: ljakoa, izoa za nakoyakoya a sikodakodan nimadjo, inika ro pacikel toa kinisedjam a nemanga.
english: But he has a bad habit of often borrowing things but not returning them.

pwn: ta vililjanga, nekanga no salasaladj a pasapasedjam tjaimadjo.
english: In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

pwn: izoa to ita qadav, vaik amen a maciyociyor a kivangavang.
english: One day, we all went on an outing together.

pwn: ta i djalan amen, mano malingav ti Uljelje, ljakoa inika napaqenetj a kemaco toa siidjoadjoas.
english: On the way, Uljelje wanted to go to the bathroom, but he forgot to bring toilet paper.

pwn: saka patjanemain a salasaladj toa sikidjoadjoas, tevelain a mayatoco, inika men a nakemaco ota ayain.
english: He borrowed toilet paper from his classmates, but everyone told him that I didn't bring them either.

pwn: qemaong anga ti Uljelje toa owalan. madodo a qivo, awa inika mon a pasedjam tjanoaken toa sikidjoadjoas aya!
english: Uljelje burst into tears. He said angrily, why don't everyone lend me toilet paper!

pwn: qaqivoin noa salasaladj a mayatoco, ayatoa inika son a nakemaco, saka no tja pasedjaman son ta nemanga, inika son a pacikecikel ota!
english: The classmate told him, because you didn't bring it yourself, and you wouldn't return the things lent to you!

pwn: ta maljiya, namedjama anga ti Uljelje i gakko, saka pacikeli a kinisedjam a nemanga toa mareka salasaladj a penoljat.
english: The next day at school, Uljelje arrived at school early and returned everything he had borrowed from his classmates.

pwn: podjavadjavai toa mareka salasaladj ti Uljelje, saka qivo a mayatoco, kiken a kemaco anga toa ko nemanga notjaivililj, saka pomaljimalji toa mareka salasaladj toa pinasedjaman tjaimadjo a pasosangas anga a qadav.
english: Uljelje apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.
My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

pwn: ta kakedriyan anan aken, no qazemezemetj vaik a casav ti kama kati kama i Kapi, nakemaco toa tjakit katoa koang.
english: When I was little, my dad and uncle Kapi would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

pwn: no maljia, nakemaco anga toa qinaljop a sacemal tiamadjo.
english: At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

pwn: nocoayanga vavoi, nocoayanga lava, panema toa padjavatan ota.
english: Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

pwn: pangapangaljen a sacemel i sipangetjez i qinaljan niamadjo, sa'a qaloti a sikataqaljan.
english: They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

pwn: ko colaqen ti kama, vaik aken a keciyor tjanoson a qemaljop ko ayain.
english: Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

pwn: olja son a meqaca anan, ko kacoav anga ayain aken ni kama/ama.
english: Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

pwn: podringai a mareka oqaljaqaljay i qinaljan toa sacemel ota, macaqo tiamadj a semanaya toa seloc katoa caqeljip/qezetj.
english: The men of the tribe also trap their prey, making lasso traps and rock traps.

pwn: macaqo aravac ti ama a seman seloc, sidringadringay co toa padjavatan aya ti ama, nia poqezeljan a djokap na sacemel, sa nia podringai a pinakazoazoanan a djaladjalan.
english: My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

pwn: aza saljinga ken a kiciyor ta ramaljeng a qemaljo, djemedje aken a kicaqoan toa seman dringay, mano inika coacoay dremingai a paroarot a ko sinanaya a dringan toa sacemel.
english: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

pwn: pacon ti ama toa ko sipodringayan, qivo a mayatoco, maljiyan toa ori lemanav son a cinonan aya.
english: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

pwn: toco a meqaca anga ken, ko sevaljen a ko vetjeljatan katoa panaq, sa'a vaik a kiciyor tjai ama a qemaljop.
english: Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

pwn: cemikel amen a sema qinaljan, nia siqalot a nia inalap a sacemel toa nia sikataqaljan.
english: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

pwn: qivo ti ama, maleva itjen toa papoloqem noa tja vovo, pinaposepiyan itjen toco a qadav.
english: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.

pwn: na sekavililj aken a sema gakko ta kadjaman.
english: I was late for school this morning.

pwn: inika na kemaco aken toa kabang, ta vaik aken a sema gakko.
english: When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.

pwn: neka no ko kinaco a nanemaneman.
english: I didn't bring anything with me.

pwn: no kitolotolo amen, pacon amen a meseljang ta laqolj katoa ko salasaladj.
english: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

pwn: no siking amen, pasedjaman aken ta inpic katoa siqoliqolip na ko salasaladj.
english: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

pwn: qivo ti sinsi tjanoaken a mayatoco, "djamao anga paceged no tjaivililj mayanga sekavililj!"
english: The teacher told me, "Wake up earlier next time and don't be late again!"

pwn: ti Poljaljoyan a ko qali, aljak noa paiwan zoko aota timadjo.
english: My good friend's name is Puljaljuyan, and he is also an Paiwan child.

pwn: kitolotolo amen i Tjaljakavos a mamav.
english: We study together in the Tjaljakavus tribe.

pwn: ro vaik amen a kilangeda ta ramaljemaljeng a menilimilingan, macaqo amen aravac a penaiwanan.
english: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Paiwan proficiently.

pwn: qacaqaca sa kodrakodral aken, kedrikedri sa koljakoljay ti Poljaljoyan.
english: I am tall and overweight, while Puljaljuyan is short and thin.

pwn: na rocikal aravac ti Poljaljoyan,kinatjengelayan timadjo noa timaimanga.
english: Puljaljuyan is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

pwn: ondokay toco a qadav noa gakko,liyav a malalomalj a pinadjolo noa gakko.
english: Today was the school's sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

pwn: izoa maqaqesir, djemakadjak ta mali, mekelj, iyoki katoa penanaq.
english: There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.
I participated in the running competition.

pwn: ta mekekelj a ken, seqolilj aken, pedjamoq to qaca a ko congal.
english: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

pwn: ljakoa migacalj aken sa na mekelj sakamaya a patjaiqayav.
english: But I stood up and continued running forward.

pwn: maleva tjorovo a caocao ta tjeljavang aken sa djaljon toa qaqacovongan.
english: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

pwn: ini na sangasangasan ljakoa namaleva ken aravac ayatoa naqemacovong aken toa malalomalj.
english: Although I didn't get first place, I'm glad because I completed the race.

pwn: na vaik amen tatiav kati kama a paljilji tjai kama i Kapi.
english: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

pwn: nasekakoda a kola ni kama i kapi.
namaperonganga a qinaljivan aya timadjo a pasemalav tjanoamen.
english: He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

pwn: na matjani timadjo a kemasi qaljiv ta seman nangoangoaq toa qaljiv.
english: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

pwn: na kemaco ti kama ta votjolj na kong katoa saviki to sipavay tja kama i Kapi.
english: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

pwn: liav a siniqivo ni kama i Kapi a milimilingan ta maljavaljavar amen i qarengan.
english: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

pwn: nameqaca sa namesaoqaljayanga son aya ti kama i Kapi a semanzoa tjanoaken ta ori vaik anga ken.
english: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

pwn: pangtjezoanga kivala a sema tjanoamen no navenalanga so kola ko ayain ti kama i Kapi.
english: I said, "When your foot gets better, come to our house next time and visit us."

pwn: ta 2022 a cavilj napakaigi a siho ta maqatianga sepapovecik a tja ngadan a kinacalisian a pitoa tja mibonsio.
english: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

pwn: nakisoso aken toa kisamoljamolja a kiqaonga toa siho ta sepapovecik a tja ngadan a kinacalisian a pitoa tja mibonsio a tja maqacovocovong i qinaljan a ti Poljaljoan.
english: I interviewed Puljaljuyan, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

pwn: na mare kicon anga men ta no toco a polavalavay vaik amen a sema ta omaq nimadjo a maljavaljavar
english: We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

pwn: ta maljavaljavar amen pasemalavan aken ta kinasizoanan noa ngadan nimadjo, sa na pakeljangi toa sikatacemekeljan nimadjo katoa qinaljan nimadjo.
english: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

pwn: ko kivadaqan timadjo to anema sikipatjemacay ta pavalit toa ngadan,a inika nangoaq a kakodan a sikipovecikan a pasosangas?
english: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn't the old registration method sufficient?

pwn: qivo timadjo tjanoaken a mayatoco, "ayatoa a tjiniokokoan inika maqati a mapasaloso a siqivoan toa ngadan nimadjo, tjorovo a caocao a ti Po sinseng aya tjaimadjo, sa napenepedjeli aravac."
english: He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him \Pu Xian Sheng

pwn: qivo ti Poljaljoyan, "a tja ngadan a vincikan toa tjavecik avanazoa tja kangadanan,a ko ngadan sinipopatarevan ta ko qinaljan ko kinacemekeljan ta ko nasi,olja napatja tjorovo a caocao a pacikel toa tjaratja ngadangadan."
english: Puljaljuyan said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

pwn: na vaik amen a semiyobay ta tiav a ti vovo i vavayan,liav a kinaco ni vovo a sinitalem nimadjo a ljaceng,sa na seman kakanen ta no kacalisian aota a sipavay ta timaimanga.
english: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

pwn: tjorovo a tjengelay ta siyobay ni vovo i vavayan, tjorovo a veneli ta silji katoa vorati, tjorovo aota a qemayam toa sinandjamay nimadjo.
english: Everyone loved my grandmother's stall. Many people bought the chilis and sweet potato, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

pwn: maljiyan to sangoaq a kinesa nimadjo a lokoc katoa djoadjoya a paday, izoa nan a cinapan a votjolj na vavoy, tjorovo a namadjaolja ta saloman, sa nacomali, a timaimanga izoa ta nia siobay.
english: The ferns and sticky rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

pwn: ta kemesakesa ti vovo i vavayan, izoa ken a tjemaotjaotjav i ljaqediqedi a ido velio ta nia sinitalem a tiamen a ljaceng, inika pinabosbosan ta cemel.
english: While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, "The vegetables are self-grown, all-natural and organic! Come and buy now!"

pwn: veliyen a pakirimorimo a nia nemanga,qivo ti vovo a mayatoco ayatoa izoa son a naposaladj a paveli aya
english: Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, "It's all thanks to your help."

pwn: pakasimaza, kitoloanga ken ta caqoan na patjara tataleman katoa kakanen na kacalisian, sa nakemeljang aota ta zelian na semiyobaobay.
english: Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

pwn: maljiyan to maleva to mapomodingan a ken ta pacon aken toa tjenglayan ni vovo i vavayan ta tja kakanen na sekacalisian.
english: Seeing my grandmother's passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.

pwn: pitjo a tokiyan ka djemaljon aken i kakitolowan a voaq.
english: I arrived at school at seven today.

pwn: patagilj anga kitolo, tjomaq ti sinsi i tatoloan, qivo a nia penovolovolong, "gacaljo! kisokobi! aya."
english: It's time for class, the teacher walked into the classroom, and the monitor said: "Stand up! Salute!"

pwn: pasiqaca amen a qivo ta, "navenala son sinsi aya amen."
ka kitolotolo amen, toloan amen ni sinsi toa sopo noa kinacalisianan.
english: In class, the teacher taught us the paiwan language of numbers.

pwn: kilayng amen tjay sinsi a semopo, semenay amen toa sasopoan a senay.
english: We followed the teacher to read, we sang the number song.

pwn: liav anga aravac a ko kinacaqo a kinacalisianan.
english: I have learned many paiwan languages.

pwn: piqadav aken a sema kakitoloan, piqadav aken a kicaqoan toa kinacalisianan, mori ko siqayvo a palangda tjay kina.
english: I go to school every day, I learn the paiwan language every day, and I want to tell my mother.

pwn: a ngadan ni kama ti Karoqo.
a ngadan ni kina ti Paoles.
toco a cavilj tapoloq anga ko cavilj.
macidilj a ko kaka a oqaljay a tjavolong, ti Qipo a ngadan nimadjo, tapoloq kato ita a cavilj nimadjo a toco a cavilj.
english: I have a brother, his name is Qipu, he is 11 years old.

pwn: itoa taytan a nia soposopoan a kakitoloan.
english: We study in the same school.

pwn: tiaken kati kaka i Qipo tjengelay amen a semenay.
english: Both my brother and I like to sing.

pwn: tjengelay aken a ljemangoy, no i potideq a qadav, tiamen a tacemekeljan vayk amen a maciocior a ljemangoy.
english: I like swimming. During the holidays, our whole family go swimming together.

pwn: tjengelay aken a kisekeljangan toa adjo, makaya amen a macior a semenay kata ljemangoy.
english: I love meeting new people, we can sing and swim together.

pwn: imazi i akav a nia omaq.
man lima a pipenoljatan a nia kinacemekeljan.
english: There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

pwn: a nia kinacemekeljan matjelo amen a marekakakaka.
english: There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

pwn: a ko kinacemekeljan izoa it kama, ti kina, tia kaka katoa tiaken.
english: I live with my father, mother, brother and sister.

pwn: kisaco a ko kama, saka qacaqaca aravac a kinalingdjeljan.
english: My father is tall and he is a policeman.

pwn: siropocemel a ko kina, saka koljakoljay aravac a kinacavacavan.
english: My mother is thin and she is a doctor.

pwn: no i tjomaq ti kama kemacalisianan tjanoamen.
english: My father speaks the paiwan language with us at home.

pwn: no kalja polavayan toa kaljazolezolan vayk amen a pasa qinaljan.
english: We will all go back to the tribe during the summer vacation.

pwn: macior amen katia kaka a kikiav.
english: My brother and sister and I will catch frogs together.

pwn: tjengelay aken aravac toa nia kinacemekeljan.
english: I like our family very much.

pwn: vayk amen a kivangavang kati kina toco a qadav.
english: I went out with my mother today.

pwn: namalingling a kalevelevan no kamaoqadavan, ika zalangzang ika vocelelj a kinaqadaqadavan, sarongoangoaq a vali.
english: The sky is blue during the day, the weather is neither cold nor hot, and the wind is cool.

pwn: keman amen toa pang itoa caocioci a kadjonangan, cenglaven a nia kinacavacavan, maseljec amen aravac.
english: We ate bread on the grass, the sun was shining on us, and it was very warm.
In the afternoon, the sky turned red.

pwn: kivadaq aken tjay kina, akozoa medjaljar a kalevelevan ko ayain.
english: I asked my mother why the sky is red.

pwn: matoco ti kina, palemek to mori mangtjez anga raljiz aya.
english: Mom said, maybe the typhoon is coming.

pwn: neka no qorepos i kalevelevan toco a qezemezemetj, sevacaq anga a vitjoqan.
english: There were no clouds in the sky at night, and the stars came out.

pwn: mori pasa omaq anga amen ota.
ka pasa omaomaq i djalan, kiligo aken toa vitjoqan.
english: On the way home, I made a wish with the stars

pwn: to ika mangtjez a raljiz, navenarong aken toa vaykanan a masasav.
english: I hope the typhoon doesn't come, I still want to go out to play again.

pwn: a nia kakitoloan izowa i tjoljivar ta nia omaq, piqadav aken a djemavac a sema kakitoloan, sake djavac ota pasa omaq.
english: My school is next to our house, I walk to school every day, and I also walk home.

pwn: inika kodral a nia kakitoloan, inika tjorovo a kitolotolo, namakakeljakeljang amen a masantalj.
english: Our school is not big, there are not many students, everyone knows each other.

pwn: azoa kakedrian a mapoljat namaqepoqepo i kakilaciqan, sa meseljaseljang a benodro, a semanljavaran.
english: All the children will gather in the playground, play ball and chat together.

pwn: a mareka sinsi kiseljang tjanoamen ota kivangavang, aico a nia kakitoloan mato tacemkeljan.
english: The teachers also play with us, the school is one big family.

pwn: piqadav amen a semoap, nia soapan a ljemengoaq aza tatoloan.
english: We have to clean every day, and everyone has to clean the classroom.

pwn: izoa vayk a zemoking toa qezong, izoa vayk a semoap.
english: Some people clean the windows, some sweep the floor.

pwn: vayk amen ota semoap toa mareka i potopotong toa kakitoloan, nia sikarasodj sa nia sikapangapangalj a sengesengan, namaljengoaq a piqadav a nia kakitoloan.
english: We will also clean every corner of the school. Everyone works together, and the school is very clean every day.

pwn: tatiav, kasiqinaljan aken a na ljemilji tjay vovo i Ubak.
english: Yesterday, I went to visit my Ubak grandpa in the tribe.

pwn: coacoay anga amen a ika mecevocevong, singelit anga aken aravac tjaymadjo.
english: We haven't seen each other for a long time and I miss him a lot.

pwn: ka pacon ti vovo i Ubak tjanoaken, pakanan aken toa siasiak, sake patekeli toa oca.
english: As soon as Ubak grandpa saw me, he invited me to eat watermelon and drink tea.

pwn: aza talem ni vovo i Ubak a siasiak qaljemeqem aravac, paqolid to sangoaq angata.
english: The watermelon grown by grandpa is very sweet and really delicious.

pwn: tjengelay aken ota toa oca ni vovo i Ubak, sangoaq aravac no tja tekelen.
english: I also like grandpa's tea, it's tasted good too.

pwn: ka kincengecengelj, kemsa amen kati vovo i Moni toa cengelj.
english: At noon, I cooked lunch with my grandma.

pwn: namakakaizoazoa a kinsa cengelj ni vovo i Moni, izoa ciqav, koka, ljasiak katoa cirat.
english: Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

pwn: no nakincengelj anga itjen, vayk anga sema poljacengan a kiljaceng.
english: After lunch, we went to the vegetable garden to pick vegetables.

pwn: malap to liav ta vorasi, ta vasa katoa laokio ti vovo i Moni, toa sipakaco tjanoaken a pasa omaq.
english: Grandma brought me a lot of sweet potatoes, taro and buckwheat, and asked me to take them home.

pwn: ko kiposaoan tiamadjo, sa ko kipazazekati to mangetezanan aken no tjayvililj a ljemilji tjayamadjo.
english: I said goodbye to them and said I'd see them next time.

pwn: kinaco amen a voaq noa nia sinsi a sema poqemozimozipan, na kitaljizan amen izowa i sitjomaq toa paljing a veneli toa kipo.
english: Today the teacher took us to the zoo, and we lined up at the gate to buy tickets.

pwn: ka temdep anga amen izowa i poqemozimozipan, qivo aza nia sinsi: "aico i paqayaqayav a mareka qayaqayam, azoa i pasalikoz a mareka qatjovi, vayko a masatalj a kitjo talido aya."
english: After entering the zoo, the teacher said, There are birds in the front and snakes in the back

pwn: marekotj aken ta qatjovi, vanasika ika aken a talido ta qatjovi.
english: I'm afraid of snakes, so I don't look at snakes.

pwn: pacon anga aken toa liav aravac a qayaqayam, i vavav toa kasiv tiamadjo a kipasasivasivalj a mipereper, izoa ota ko pinaconan a ljeqo a nataqed itoa boang noa kasiv.
english: I saw a lot of birds flying around in the trees and saw owls sleeping in tree hollows.

pwn: azoa i poqemozimozipan izoa zao, rigi kata likoljav, inia ke pacon toa mareka qemozimozip a kemasicoay, toco a vaoaq a qadav kanapacon anga aken maleva aken aravac.
english: There are elephants, horses and tigers in the zoo. I have never seen these animals before. I was really happy to see them today.

pwn: liav aravac a ko pinasiasingan, sa ko papaconan tjay kama kati kina.
english: I took a lot of pictures and showed them to my parents.

pwn: no tjayvililj ori kicior aken tjay kama kati kina a semamaza.
english: Next time I will come with my parents.

pwn: toco no sipolavayan a qadav, vayk amen kati kaka i Babay a sema Valangao a kivala tjay kama i Koliv.
english: This holiday, my sister Baby and I went to Taitung to visit my uncle Kuliv.

pwn: na makavavav amen toa ljiok a kemasi taipaq a pasa valangan.
english: We took the train from Taipei to Taitung.

pwn: ka djemaljon amen i valangan, kicacevongen amen a mapopalidringan toa palidring ni kama i Koliv.
english: When we arrived in Taitung, my uncle drove to the station to pick us up.

pwn: azoa popalidringan inika cadja toa omaq ni kama i Koliv, no makavavav itjen toa palidring palamo satje djaljon.
english: The station is not far from my uncle's house, and it's just a short drive away.

pwn: azoa i dodot toa omaq ni kama i Koliv izoa za maljekodral a papaqozipan toa qemozimozip, vayk amen a maka tolay a macior a sema papaqozipan toa qemozimozip.
english: There is a big ranch near my uncle's house, and we rode bicycles to the ranch together.

pwn: ka izoa amen i papaqozipan toa qemozimozip, kacoin amen ni kama i Koliv a pakan toa sizi katoa tjevavav toa rigi.
english: In the ranch, my uncle took us to feed the sheep and ride horses.

pwn: ka qezemezemetj, vayk amen a macior a sema lemizokan a keman.
english: In the evening, we went to the city to have dinner together.

pwn: azoa i lemizokan liav aravac a palidring, vanasika namaka otobay amen a pasa zowa.
english: There are a lot of cars in the city, so we go there by motorcycle.

pwn: ka mori pasa vayk amen, mano cinakav anga otobay, pay pasa amin anga nia makavavav toa baso a vayk izowa.
english: When we were about to leave, we found that the motorcycle had been stolen, so we had to leave by bus.

pwn: toco djemaljon anga amen i taipaq, qadjav toki namadjomak anga a otobay ni kama i Koliv.
english: Now that we are back in Taipei, I don't know if my uncle's motorcycle has been found.

pwn: ka kakedrian aken imaza i kazangiljan a nia omaq, ka kitolo anga aken, setavat anga amen a mamaza i Akav, imaza amen sakamaya i lizok a kikavaljovaljot.
english: When we were young, our family lived in Chiayi. After I started school, we moved to Pingtung and have been living in the city ever since.

pwn: ka semopo anga aken toa sikipakelayan a kakitoloan, kitolo aken to masan italj toa pakata kakodakodan noa kacalisian a kakitoloin, silaotan toa namakakaizoazoa namalavi a kakodakodan noa i taivang a kacalisian.
english: After I went to college, I took a course on aboriginal culture and learned that the aboriginal people in Taiwan have various and rich cultures.

pwn: vanasika, toco a cavilj no sikalja polavayan toa kaljazolezolan, mori vayk amen kati kaka i Cemelesay a sema qinaljan a kivavadaq toa vavolongan, navenarong amen to lemaot toa driniongan noa nia kakodakodan.
english: So this summer, my brother and I went back to our tribe to visit the elderly, hoping to understand the culture of our own ethnic group.

pwn: azoa vavolongan alo anga poloq a cavilj, ljakoa no tjapaconan mato i cengeceng a kinacaviljan.
english: The old man is already eighty years old, but he still looks like a middle-aged man.

pwn: ko kivadaqan timadjo to anemanema no kayan a kacaqoin, aza nimadjo a Vinocoljan solapiq a siqaqivoan, macaqo ota qivo toa Drinkayan, Kinilangan kata Drinipongan.
english: I asked him which languages he knew, and he was fluent in Paiwan, as well as Rukai, Hakka and Japanese.

pwn: ka ko kivadaqan anga timadjo kemljang anga aken, to mano kemasi kedrikedri a kicaqoan toa (Drinipongan, a cekelj seRokai, ao aza itoa sengesengan nasekeljang toa tjorovo aravac a Kilang, vanasika liav a kacaqoin a kay nimadjo.
english: I asked him to find out that he learned Japanese when he was a child, his wife is an Rukai, and he knows many Hakkas at work, so he can speak so many languages.

pwn: no kivadavadaq amen, aza ramaljemaljeng masan lialiav aravac a pakata kinasicoay a kinljangan toa siqaljopan a sipareqaivoivo.
english: During our interview, the old man talked about a lot of traditional knowledge about hunting.

pwn: oito inika amen a makapocog a pipenoljatan, ljakoa nia siniposeqetj anga paseqailjongan a pitoa pinilima a ljingas, makaya siomaljanan sa sileqeleq a kisalangda.
english: Although we could't fully understand it, we could record it on our cell phones and listen to it more.

pwn: ka kakedrianan aken ika aken a nalemaot toa kakodakodan noa ko kinadriongan, pitoa ko kinakacalisianan izoa za ko siaqan.
english: When I was young, I didn't understand the culture of my ethnic group, and I was a little embarrassed that I was an aborigine.

pwn: no tjaliav anga ko linaot, patjazoa ko kinavarongan toa kinasePaiwanan, na remamor a kinisomaljian, mapoqata ota a simiazoan.
english: The more I know, the more I feel that being a Paiwan is unique and something to be proud of.

pwn: toco a qadav no masolesolem, mori sema omaq a ko kaka ti Ljegeay.
english: My younger brother Ljegeay is going home this evening.

pwn: na vayk amen kati vovo i Saoniav a matatakayan a veneli toa koka, mori nia kesain a semangoangoaq toa pinadjolo to kaiven ni Ljegeay a ko kaka.
english: My grandma and I went to the market to buy chickens and prepared a delicious dinner for my younger brother.

pwn: ka cemalivat amen toa temakatakay ta ljaceng, aza sitakatakay a ljaceng liva anan azoa namilidji a tjaokaljaceng.
english: We passed the vegetable stand, which had a lot of fresh green vegetables.

pwn: na veneli anga amen toa incay, toa qaqilj kata qodidilj a caytav.
english: We bought water spinach, yams and carrots.

pwn: aza i tjoljivar a temakatakay toa vangalj a rotakatakay qivo a matoco, "aico a ko pangodral kata qodis qaljemeqem aravac. pay velio a popida lja aya!"
english: The owner of the nearby fruit stand said: "My pineapples and peaches are very sweet. Buy some!"

pwn: na veneli amen toa pangodral kata qodis.
ka cemalivat amen toa temakatakay toa votjolj, aza rotakatakay qivo a matoco, "anema so velin? aico a koka a voaq kakodralan saka na venotjolj, no taitan tjelo a iday a vatanan." aya.
english: We passed the meat stall, and the boss said, "What do you want to buy? Today's chickens are big and fat, and one is 300 NTD."

pwn: paka pazangal aravac ti vovo i Saoniav, pay sa kivadaq toa za rotakatakay to aki makaya patjamadjoloin.
english: Grandma thought it was too expensive and asked the boss if it could be cheaper.

pwn: ljakoa azoa rotakatakay matoco sinipomadjolo anga aravac, inika anga makaya patjamadjoloin aya.
english: But the boss said that it is already very cheap and cannot be reduced any further.

pwn: azowa i ljaqedi a rotakatakay matoco a qivo, keljo velio toa ko ciqav, aico a ko ciqav kakodrakodralan saka madjolo aya.
english: The boss next door said, come and buy my fish, my fish is big and cheap.

pwn: ka vililj anga veneli anga amen toa koka sane veli ota toa ciqav, sa satjomaq a kemsa to tadataran toa djamay.
english: In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.

pwn: coay anga kiljaljavaljava, mizemzem anga qadav.
english: After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

pwn: na papangtjez toa ljingas a ko kaka ti Ljegeay a matoco, na papintjos aza i posivitjayan to inika makaya polavay, no tjaivililj anga sipolavayan a qinadavan mana mangtjez anga aken aya.
english: The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn't take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

pwn: matoco a qivo ti vovo i Saoniav liav a ko kinsa, pay pokanoi a masantalj aya.
english: Grandma said that she has cooked so much, so let's eat together!

pwn: na cemged amen toa mareka nia vetjek toa nia adjoadjo, a kipomangtjez a kipatjingoaq toa napenakakaizoan a kaiven.
english: We invited friends and family to have a great dinner together.

pwn: izoa za ko seljaseljang a ti Comay, ro alim a kemaco ta nemanga.
english: I have a classmate named Cumay, he often forgets to bring things.

pwn: no sikitolotoloan, kisedjam timadjo toa seljaseljang ta sivecivecik, ta siqoliqolip kato vavecikan.
english: During class, he borrowed pencils, erasers or notebooks from his classmates.

pwn: si kintalj, si kinmosalj, si kintjelolj a nemanga sipasedjasedjam tjaimadjo niamen a masantalj.
english: Once, twice, three times, everyone would lend him something.

pwn: ljakoa izoa za nakoya a kakodan nimadjo, ro kisedjam toa nema sa ika pacikel.
english: But he has a bad habit of often borrowing things but not returning them.

pwn: ka vililj anga neka anga no venarong toa pasedjam to nemanga tjanoamen a pimasantaljan.
english: In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

pwn: izoa ka itoa to qadav, vayk amen a macior a masantalj a kivangavang.
english: One day, we all went on an outing together.

pwn: ka i djalan tazoa, mano malingav ti Comay to masaosavan, ljakoa namalim timadjo a masi qocic.
english: On the way, Cumay wanted to go to the bathroom, but he forgot to bring toilet paper.

pwn: pasa kisedjam timadjo toa nia seljaseljang ta qocic, ljakoa nia tevelain a masantalj, to ika aken a nakemaco ota niayain.
english: He borrowed toilet paper from his classmates, but everyone told him that I didn't bring them either.

pwn: mano patjeljaqaong ti Comay ka maqotjav, madodo timadjo sa mayatoco, ako ika aken a no pasedjaman toa qocic a masantalj aya!
english: Cumay burst into tears. He said angrily, why don't everyone lend me toilet paper!

pwn: pasemalavan timadjo noa seljaseljang, ayatoa ika son a kitjo kaco toa nemanga, sa aza sinipasedjam tjanoson a nemanga, ika son angata a pacikel ayain!
english: The classmate told him, because you didn't bring it yourself, and you wouldn't return the things lent to you!

pwn: ka macepeliv a qadav toa sisa kakitoloan, na medjama sa djaljon i kakitoloan ti Comay, sa aza mareka kinisedjasedjam toa seljaseljang ni Comay a nemanga pacikelen tjanoamen a seljaseljang.
english: The next day at school, Cumay arrived at school early and returned everything he had borrowed from his classmates.

pwn: kipaqaljay tjanoamen a seljaseljang ti Comay, sa mayatoco timadjo kemasi toco a qadav tjara kitjo kaco anga aken toa nemanga aya, maljimalji ota toa tjanomon a ko seljaseljang aico a sitjaisangasan a nasecalivat anga pokaoy mon a pasedjama toa nemanga tjanoaken aya.
english: Cumay apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.

pwn: ti kama namasan roqaljoqaljop i qinaljan.
english: My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

pwn: ka kakedrian aken, ti kama kati kama i Koljelje no salilim a sivaivaik a sasav, sa namasi takit kata koang.
english: When I was little, my dad and uncle would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

pwn: no qoljan anga, mangtjez anga tiamadjo a namasi qinaljop.
english: At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

pwn: izoa no vavoy, izoa no lava, izoa ota no namasi padavatan.
english: Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

pwn: tiamadjo pangaljen aza qinaljop, sa pangapangaljan toa sikataqaljan.
english: They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

pwn: noaya makaljavay aken, toa kiayan tjaikama a qemaljop.
english: Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

pwn: matoco ti kama no ljemto anga son ko ciorav anga a kemaco aya.
english: Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

pwn: aza i qinaljan a oqaljaqaljay macaqo ota poraong toa sacemel, macaqo tiamadjo a poseloc kata poqacev.
english: The men of the tribe also trap their prey, making lasso traps and rock traps.

pwn: macaqo aravac ti kama seman poseloc, matoco ti kama, aico a sidjamedjameq toa padavatan, tjagetjemen a kileqeleq a djinkapan noa sacemel, aico a siniporaong tjapizoain itoa sinangalivan noa sacemel aya.
english: My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

pwn: toa sikitaloan a kiayan toa tjavavolongan a qemaljop, piqdav aken a kicaqoan toa seman qaljangetj, ika nacoay aza ko sinan poraong makay anga paqolid a djemameq toa sacemel.
english: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

pwn: ka napacon anga ti kama mayatoco tjanoaken no tjaivililj tjara son a masan djoljam toa siqaljopan aya.
english: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

pwn: toco ljemto anga aken, ko siniljavac a semevalj aza ko tiveljatan kata vakela, sake vayk a kicior tjaikama a qemaljop.
english: Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

pwn: ka djemaljon amen i qinaljan nia sipangapangalj a semiljeva za nia qadav toa nia sikataqaljan.
english: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

pwn: matoco ti kama, maleva itjen toa papomangoaqan noa tja tjaisangasangas, saka izoa sa liav aravac a tja qimang aya.
english: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.

pwn: ka kadjaman na gemaljo aken a talo gako.
english: I was late for school this morning.

pwn: ko alimen a ko kaban, ka ma gako aken.
english: When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.
I didn't bring anything with me.

pwn: miseljan amen ka ta ko ali a pacon toa hon ni madjo, ka somoposopo amen.
english: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

pwn: pinasedjam aken toa sisopisopil, ka ta inpic nako ali ka sikin amen.
english: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

pwn: ivo aniya sinsi tja noaken "maya sa gemaljoanga midjamao a paceked!"
english: The teacher told me, "Wake up earlier next time and don't be late again!"

pwn: tji solja ko ali a ravac a ljak na kacalisia a ngota tji madjo.
english: My good friend's name is sulja, and he is also an paiwan child.

pwn: ko salad a somopo i djiniljepan.
english: We study together in the djiniljepan tribe.

pwn: lemandandamen toa sinimilingang kemasi to nija vavolongna si ka makeyamen na kemacalisyanang.
english: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Paiwan proficiently.

pwn: acaaca aken korakoral aken tji silja kerikeri' sa koljakoljai a ngaota.
english: I am tall and overweight, while sulja is short and thin.

pwn: ginki tji solja, tjengelai ya tjimaimanga
english: sulja is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

pwn: ondokaidokai a nia gako a toco, masanliao a kamoko a ro si pisaipisai.
english: Today was the school's sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

pwn: izoa mavaviljevilj, temokoros to a mali, zemian kata penana'.
english: There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.
I participated in the running competition.

pwn: na matjani a ken ka mekekelj,saka na pedjamo' a ko conganlj.
english: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

pwn: ljakoa,,migacal a ekn sa mekelj a pacoso.
english: But I stood up and continued running forward.

pwn: ka macovong a ken, na maleva a tjimaimanga.
english: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

pwn: sa ini' kaken a na tjamakaya, ljkoa maleva aken to ko ina covon.
english: Although I didn't get first place, I'm glad because I completed the race.

pwn: na vaik aken ka tji kama a ljemizao tjai kama i paljan.
english: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

pwn: na mapasae'tjo a kola ni kama i paljan.
pasemalao tji kama i paljan tja noamen aza oma' nji madjo na maboan a za aljo.
english: He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

pwn: ka ljemongoa' tji madjo makelo a kema si aljo.
english: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

pwn: tji kama na kemaco to a votjol na ljoan kata saviki aro sipantez tjai kama i paljan.
english: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

pwn: na imilad aken katji kama i paljan i ta tataedan ni madjo sa pasemalamalao tja no ken ta canalivatan ni madjo.
english: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

pwn: ka ro vaik anganken zemenger tji kama i paljan tja noaken na mea'canga sa saoa'lai yanga son aya.
english: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

pwn: no sarongoa' angang so kola kivalao a matja noamen ayaken na kiposao tji kama i paljan.
english: I said, "When your foot gets better, come to our house next time and visit us."

pwn: ka 2022 a cavilje a tja siho ljemaoi to makayanga akipavecik toa tjia kinacalisianan a ngadan pita nibonsio.
english: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

pwn: na kiaivoan aken to na kisamolja coacoai a tji solja pakata venecik a pita nibonsio a kinacalisian a ngadan.
english: I interviewed sulja, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

pwn: na mareaivo amen. to micevon no nicio a mata oma' nji mado.
english: We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

pwn: ka tazoa, pasemalaovin a ken to a na kemasino sa ngada nji madjo sa siokai toa matjaljaljak kata inljan nji madjo.
english: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

pwn: kivada' aken nakoya a tja sikivecikan na tjoco ako son a kiaon to paomaljin?
english: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn't the old registration method sufficient?

pwn: temevela tji madjo, a ljinaotjian na vinecikan ini' ka makaya lemoloai toa ko kinacalisianangn a ngadan mapasaliokamaya liao a napasamli sa sikapedjelian.
english: He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him \Shu Xian Sheng

pwn: na ivo tji solja a kinacalisianang a sivecikan pa'olid to njitjen na ngadan. njitjen na zokoan tja kina cemekeljan atja djmo' olja na makaya a tjatjorovo a caocao a kipavecik toatja kinacalisianang a ngadan.
english: cemelesai said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

pwn: ka tjiyao vaik amen ka tji vovo a sema papaveliyan a paveli,na kemaco tji vovo to a makara ljacen,sa na seman kakanen a ngaota ta ro sipaveli.
english: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

pwn: tjenglai a caocao toa nji vovo a siobai, aza silji kata ljameljam mapa veli a ravac, sa tjorovo a ngaotan a caocao to keman ta kinesa nji vovo.
english: Everyone loved my grandmother's stall. Many people bought the chilis and ginger, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

pwn: aza cinavo ka ta pino ljameljam a kinsa kata pino makao a votjolj na vavoi salom sa na masiop pa makara caocao sa tjorovo a na paitoi i ta na siobai.
english: The taro buns and ginger rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

pwn: no kemesakesa tji vovo tjaken a paveliveli, sa ko pasiaca a zemalazala. tjiamen a na tejmalem ini' a katjedokoan keljo keljo velio.
english: While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, \The vegetables are self-grown

pwn: palamo maka paveli a ngamen. tjison sa na makaya tjen na mayatoco aya tji vovo a ivo tja noaken.
english: Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, \It's all thanks to your help.\""

pwn: aico a njia kinianan a siobaibbai liao angan ko kineljan a pa ka tana kacalisian a djami a kakanen sa na pavavalanga ken to zelian no siobaibai.
english: Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

pwn: a povarongan kata tjengelaiyan nji vovo toa kakaen na kinacalisianan na masi miazoan kata masilevan aken a ravac.
english: Seeing my grandmother's passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.
