pwn: pai, kinemnemanga tiamadjo to kemaco toa ljigim noa kakinan.
english: Now, they decided to take their mother's sewing needles.

pwn: pai, inika makakiqadilj tia marekaka toa kipaola toa coljan.
english: Now, the two brothers can no longer take the suffering and hunger.

pwn: pai, paqozipanga noa kina a kaka a tjaljaljak toa kama niamadjo.
english: It comes to that they are raised by aunt, their father's younger sister.

pwn: pai pai, samalji a ko salasaladj toa patjara mavoca a caocao.
english: Thereupon, my classmates are curious about blind people.

pwn: kolio: namadraodraw aken a kemaco toa ko binto. codjoi: pai nomayan tjakanaoanga ko binto. kolio: bolai a vaik itjen a ljemangoi? codjoi: bolai aravac. pai, ari vaiki. kolio: qemodjaljanga. inika aken a nakemaco toa kaosoa. maqati aken a sopasedjaman? codjoi: ita a ko kaosoa. pai, kadjadjalani a kiljaong. aico djokap noa vavoi. pai, aico avan a djaladjalan noa vavoi.
english: kuliu: I forgot to bring my lunch box. cudjui: come, in that case, let's eat my lunch box.

pwn: vovo vavayan, ti kolio 'a ti paljai amen. pai, soqeljevi amen. pai, qiladjo. anema so'anen?
english: Grandma, it's kuliu and paljai. Please open the door for us.

pwn: pai, kosoalapav a dengec i toa so modingan.
english: Come, let me get the crumbs off your face.

pwn: pai, kipapaolingavo. akomayanga sa so tjengez?
english: Come on, get it all together. Why are you dozing off like this?

pwn: pai, mayanan maya penorpor a so kaka. pai, maya mano seman-neka-aravac toa zoma. pai, kiomaljo. semiaq sa so sikodan.
english: Do not yet disturb your brother.

pwn: ljaljeqeljeqel aico a kinsa. pai, seljecoanan. pai, pasazalemani a remasodj toa tjakinepel a qavai. olja tjen a kemeljang to pidanga sopo a penoljat.
english: The food is already cold. Go, heat it.

pwn: pai, senasenayo. masepelj itjen. pai, maya qemalovo a tja kinateveteveljan.
english: Come, sing a song. We are bored.

pwn: maya masepelj a siqono ni so vovo, aya aken tjanoson. inika son a lemang da. pai, mavociqanga a so lima. maljengoaqanga aza koang, pai?
english: I told you not to play wioth your grandpa's small knife. You didn't listen. Look, your hand is cut.

pwn: inika son narokisasoso toa mareka tjakaka, pai sipavai toa zoma a hio niamadjo.
english: You did not take good care of our brothers and sisters, therefore they gave their votes to others.

pwn: saqetjo a ko kaka, manosika inika kasikakitoloan. pai manasika a i taiwan mavan a ko qinaljan, ota aya aken.
english: My brother is ill, therefore he did not go to school

pwn: naminseg a ljavek, ayatoa neka no vali.
english: The sea has calmed down because there is no wind.

pwn: kipaola aravac tiamadjo ta ico a qodjalj, ayatoa siniqaljodj a qoma.
english: They suffer severely from this rain, because the farm was washed away.

pwn: ayatoa a picol a ligo nisonanga a penoljat a kemasi toco a patje palalaotanga. amin.
english: Because power, honor, all belongs to you, from now until forever. amen.

pwn: inianga kapazangal a kemesa toco, ayatoa izoanga a tinko. ayatoa a benoro ori si'atarivak na 'o lingalingaw.
english: Because of electrical rice cooker, it is no longer difficult to cook now.

pwn: djaljepan a kisasoso aravac tjajoaken a nia sinsi, mano seljaseljang ni kama kisansinsi. djaljepan to kemavason toa bolabolay, avan sosikabolay.
english: So that's why my teacher cares very much for me, because he was dad's colleague at school.

pwn: sedjaljepson a kisankalaingan. a kisedjaljep a mayatocoson a makinamalji?
selep: ori venli aken to drosa a djaljeng a nigi. dremedreman: izoa a tjelo a djaljeng imaza. nisonaianga a penoljat.
english: selep: I want to buy two bunches of green onions. dremedreman: There are three bundles here. They are all yours.

pwn: tadjaljeng azoa qarizang. djemaljeng aken toa ravoc.
english: That is a handful/bundle/sheaf of yardlong beans. Word gloss:

pwn: madjadjaljdjalj amen ka ti kaka i selep.
english: I am next to (subsequent to) selep in the ranking of siblings. I am are youner than selep. [selep is the eldest, and I am the second-born.]
uni is the second among the siblings.

pwn: djaljaw angata no mekelj timadjo. tjadjaljaw a makahikoki toa makagongkang.
english: He is really fast when he runs.
How many bundles of wood do you have?
That wood fiber is very hard.
There in Mount kavuliungan, it is filled with pristine forest.

pwn: inika makaya a maqodjalj a pokasivan.
english: The place where the woods are cannot catch rain.
As soon as I dive in, I accidentally catch mussels.

pwn: nakidjadjas ti kama toa paljing. kosipadjadjas a saosi noa 'omaq ta koqali.
inika aken a padjadjas a paqeteleng toa paiso.
english: I do not entrust my money to anyone casually.

pwn: nadjemadjas a ko kaka toa vorasi.
nosaoni posaladjoanga a qemarot ta aljoaljo.
english: In a while you help giving away the candies.

pwn: no qemaroqarot itjen toa nemanga, nakoya inika papamamaw.
english: When we alloting or distributing things, it is not good to not give the same [it is bad to be unfair].

pwn: qaroto ta mareka a sinsi aico a kamaya.
english: Please send these mangoes to every teacher.

pwn: siqarot a vidoat na takec toa mamazangiljan.
english: Give the share of the ribs of the Reeves's muntjac to the chief.

pwn: no naqemodjalj, vaik aken a ljemoljo toa ngacingaci.
english: If it rains, I will go collecting snails.
Flour is very good for our body.
Do not go near the fire, you will be burnt.
Harvest festival is just around the corner.

pwn: madadet aravac azoa nosinitalem a kasiw.
english: Those trees you planted are too crowded. [Semantic subject is ERGATIVE].

pwn: tjadedet a paqolid a no pinarecongoljanan.
english: Your blood relation is really closer. [You are really closer in blood relation.]

pwn: dedet anan a tja pinarekakakakakan. pacaingan a gong a pidedet.

english: Fall is indeed already around the corner.

pwn: idedet a nia qinaljan a kemasi maza.
english: Our village is close from this place. [Our village is nearby.]

pwn: dongdong a sema yobingkioko a kemasi tjanoamen.
english: It is close to go to the post office from our place.

pwn: nakeman ta podoko a kakanen timadjo, kirimo, vaikan a papocemel.
english: He ate poisonous food. Hurry up, send him to the doctor.

pwn: izoa 'o taiday a qadopo a valjitjoq, sa 'ivalit a'en.
english: I have a 100-dollar bill, and I want to change.

pwn: no qivo itjen, nakoya a masidodoan.
english: When we speak, it is not good to carry anger.
Just now I was really scolded by mom.

pwn: anema so kodain a kikadodo tjai tja'ma?
english: What are you doing, pissing off our dad like that?

pwn: tjaljadodoan aken toa venca. an en in
english: I am most mad about lying.
Mouse is such a headache. (Mouse is really annoying or Mouse angers people a lot.)

pwn: a so siqaqivoan papododoan aravac toa zoma.
english: The way you speak really infuriates other people.

pwn: a sikodan na aico a tiza deminodo aravac.
english: The behavior of this guy is really infuriating.

pwn: madodo aken aravac toa so kinodan.
english: I am very mad at what you did.

pwn: madaqay a napadjele itjen toa rosoko, izoa tjasikipaqolja toco a vengin.
english: How fortunate that we have prepared candles, therefore we have some light tonight.

pwn: kamayan a bobong i ta qovalj. benobong aravac a zaqo.
english: There's still suds on the hair. Soap lathers quite easily.

pwn: kivi: nima aico a tjalopong? kolio: nia'en aico a tjalopong.
english: kivi: Whose hat is this? kuliu: This hat is mine.

pwn: vaik a benosbos ta pokamayan timadjo.
english: He went to spray pesticide in his mango garden.

pwn: inika son a nakiqenetj to pomoqanga a so kola?
english: Did you not notice your leg is festering?

pwn: kolio: bolai a vaik itjen a benolo ta lancio? coidjoi: bolai! ari vaiki.
english: Is it good that we go playing basketball?

pwn: no minatok, makesa a tja kinsa.
english: When it comes to boil, our rice is cooked.

pwn: ayatoa iniyanan kamacaqo ti lanpaw a ljemangoi, kaljemanoi timadjo, seboqboq.
english: Because lanpaw has not yet learned swimming, as he swam, he got drowned.

pwn: makakananga a bongo ta tja qinoman.
english: Grasshoppers are devouring our farm produce.
Get water with the bucket. [Literally a UV structure: The bucket is a place filled with water.]

pwn: kasicoayan a tjakakesain a paiwan naliyaw aravac. izoa vasa, vorasi, kalaloma, djolis, veljevelj kata padai.
english: Since a long ago in the past, we Paiwan had a lot of food grains. There were potato, sweet potato, oat, banana and rice.

pwn: sinsi: bolabolaymon? toco a qadaw, ori kacoinmon noa sinsi a sema qinaljan a kivala toa ramaljemaljeng. sito: bolay yo. ori qivo amen toa kai a pinaiwanan kata ramljemaljeng.
english: Teacher: How you are? Today, I will take you to the village to visit elders. Students: That's great. We want to speak Paiwan language with the elders.

pwn: a sapoljoan noa cinonan a caocao mavan a kasizoanan noa garang katoa picol niamadjo.
english: Solitute for hunters is the source of their spiritual power and strength.

pwn: liaw aravac a vociyar i pasaqayaw tjayamadjo.
english: There are many flowers in front of their house.
There is a hole in my pants.
Get rid of that dog. [Drive away that dog.]

pwn: inika tjengelay aken a pecaqi toa i casaw a kakivaliyan.
english: I don't like to use the toilet outside for number 1.

pwn: inika napaqozip tia vovo toa bibi.
english: Grandpa and grandma did not raise ducks.

pwn: neka tja pacoconan a rigi i pasa maza tjanoitjen.
english: Horse is not seen by us at our place. [We don't have horses in our place.]

pwn: kolavaw a nakemac sa benerong ta sikaw.
english: A mouse bit the backpack and made a hole.

pwn: nakoya paberiq itjen i toa kinateveteveljan noa caocao.
english: It is bad to fart in the crowds.

pwn: nakoya a semanberaq itjen toa nasemalimsim a caocao.
english: It is bad to look down on poor people.
Having a stuffy nose is quite uncomfortable.

pwn: nison aico a bao, ljengoaqo a kiposengsengan. benao ti kama ta qaqomain. kibao timadjo ta sengsengan.
english: This is your part, do the work well. Dad handles all the work at the farm. He gets the contract of the work.
We build houses with ballast and cement.

pwn: carogcog a ciopan no qemodjalj. alapo toa ko ljingas i ta haiya. masanliawliaw a patek imaza.
english: When it rains, corrugated iron sheets make hitting noise.

pwn: maleva aravac tiaken ka pacon tjanomon a mapoljat.
english: I feel very happy to see all of you.

pwn: namasanpazangal a qinoman a veljevelj i tjanoitjen a paiwan.
english: Banana is an important crop for us Paiwan people.

pwn: mabanal ti kama. palemek a ori mabanal aken no tjaivililj.
english: Dad is bald. Maybe I will become bald later.

pwn: no qemodjalj, patalav itjen toa bakico a pililjililjing.
english: When it's raining, we put a bucket to catch water falling from the eaves.

pwn: neka tjapacoconan a rigi i pasamaza tjanoitjen.
english: We do not see horses in our place. [Literally: Horse is not seen by us in the place of us.]

pwn: parekiljivaljivako a marekakakaka aya a kai ni kama.
english: Love each other, so is the word of Dad [so Dad says].

pwn: a kai noa caocao namasan vavak noa kacalisiyan i taiwan.
english: Human language is the soul of indigenous peoples in Taiwan.

pwn: napoamin ti giao toa paveli toa kakanen.
english: giau has finished the sale of food. [giau has closed the restaurant.]

pwn: maljian a qoljaw na kakakaka na amilika.
english: The color of the pupils of Americans is different.

pwn: gemiring a likoljaw sa pasamintjos ti kedrikedri a vavayan, qao kiqilja ma ta tapatapaw. liaw sa qao imaza.
english: Clouded-leopard roars, then the little girl got scared, and look, she runs to hide in the hut. qau: bamboo liaw sa qau imaza. Free translation: There is a lot of bamboos here.

pwn: kaiv amen sane pacon ta vitjoqan.
english: We have dinner, then we watch stars.

pwn: sarokoya masik i povasan no qemodjaqodjalj.
english: It's hard work to weed in the potato farm on a rainy day.

pwn: izoa toco a kinaroporopong, tjangtjang / siyak, asaw na vorasi 'ata roni.
english: Today there are cabbage, pumkin, sweet potato leaves and sponge gourd.

pwn: no semoap a masalot avan a masak ta palisian na paiwan.
english: Sweeping the floor to clear the way after a harvest ritual represents is a Paiwan custom.

pwn: aico a kavaloan sinipakialap toa maseqetjan noa vavayan.
english: This lily is used to represent the chastity of women.
It is not good that we become proud.

pwn: no vaik a cinonan a semagado, kemaco ta aradj.
english: When a hunter heads to the mountains, he brings crisp dried taro.
I am looking for my pen.

pwn: nakoya mapoapo sa qivoqivo, inika maljaloai a so kai.
english: Do not talk while chewing betel nuts. You slur your words.

pwn: "tjara son a mazelianga toa so kinaivavavan ta kasiw. ido, satekoanga a kisozeliyan," aya ti gang.
english: "You must be tired staying on the tree. Come, climb down and rest," so said the crab.

pwn: s aqetjo a caljedjen na pangac. poaljo a tjainan.
angata caocaoangata. sangoaqangata a tja papa a kacalisiyan.
english: It's really a person! Indigenous cuisine is really tasty.

pwn: angalj aico a tja angalj, tja sikakan, tja sikaqivoqivo.
english: This mouth of ours, we use to eat, we use when speaking.

pwn: anga vaik-anga ti kam -anga ti Utjong-anga vaikanga timadjo.
inika mapasoso a ko varong. masoram aken aravac.
english: I didn't find what I wanted. I feel very disappointed.

pwn: liaw a amis noa azoa vorasi.
english: That sweet potato contains a lot of fibers.

pwn: kitolo amen toa inamirikan a ljemita ta qadaw.
poarai ti kama i pana a kiciqaw.
english: Father is casting a net in the rivier to catch fish.
We are leaving for Taipei soon.

pwn: aico a sapoi katoa zaljom mamaw a kinamasanpazangalan toa tja nasi.
english: This fire and water, they are equally important to our life.
My father is a brilliant hunter who always catches game.
There are eight birds on the roof.
The two of them walked uphill with arms around each other's shoulders.

pwn: no mevolong a caocao, madjeleanga a maalim a ngadan noa zoma.
english: When people get old, other people's name is easy to be forgotten.

pwn: maretimaljimaljianga a qoljaw na alay toco.
english: Nowadays threads have different colors. [Literally: Now the color of threads is already different.]

pwn: naseminamalji a caqoan noa komakoma a semankaljoalaq.
english: Spiders are suprisingly talented in making webs. [Literally: Spiders' web-making talent is amazing.]

pwn: alapen a nia paiso na cemakacakaw.
english: A thief stole our money. [Literally: Our money was stolen by a thief.]

pwn: aladji saladji. pasaladji. saladji a kemim.
english: No, I don't want to. No, I don't want to. Forget i, don't bother trying to find it.
Add sugar to the liquor later.
Your glass beads are very pretty.

pwn: navaik ti kama tatiyaw a kipocemel toa aljis.
english: Dad went to get medicine for the teech [see the dentist] yesterday.

pwn: pinaka toa ngadan ni yiso kiristo a inoli, amen.
english: In Jesus Christ's name we pray, amen.

pwn: akoken a samalji toa so sikodan.
english: I am surprised at your behaviour.
How many kids do you have?

pwn: alapo toa sialja sa sevalji a so kaka.
english: Take that baby wrap and carry your sister on the back.

pwn: a-ken tiaken a navaik a ma ripon. akoson a kemeljang tjanoaken?
english: It was I who went o Japan. Why do you know me?

pwn: a-ino ino aino a kaos? ko sikaos ta siyaw. ino a 'o sivecivecik?
english: Where is the soup spoon? I use it to serve soup. Where is my pen?

pwn: ago napenalisi toa paqozip ta gong 'asicoaiyan.
english: In the past herding cattles was considered a taboo.

pwn: namadjoq a ko ljinay i qaqeregan.
english: My umbrella was left in the room.

pwn: adjaq aico a cakar namasan kakitoloan noa mimaqacovocovongan a oqaljaqaljay.
english: This men's house has become the school of young men who are turning into adults.

pwn: abonai aravac a sapoi. gemagalj aravac azoa a djalan.
english: Fire is very dangerous. That road is very dangerous.

pwn: no temolotolo a vavolovolongan, naljiabar a tjacalinga a lemangdangda.
english: If the elders are teaching, we open our ears and listen.

pwn: liyaw a talem ni kama a abar.
english: The coconut trees planted by father are a lot. (Father plants many coconut trees).

pwn: nanangoaqan aravac a mareka tia Pia.
english: Pia and those with him, everyone is very nice.

pwn: masatemolo toa sinzia, pai ' a i 1951 izoa rotjaocikecikel a kemasi ingeris a bokesi a ti yohani, sinkaoljan a pasa ta qinaljan noa sepaiwan. ' itolo timadjo toa kai na pinaiwanan, sa posaladj a ' emomalj toa pinaiwanan a sisio'atoa sambika, sa a patagiljanga a vencik toa pinaiwanan a kai.
english: In order to teach believers, see, in 1952, there was a pastor and missionary, yuuhani (Reverend John Whitehorn), from England,. he was sent to the villages of the Paiwan people. He studied the Paiwan language, and helped to change the Bible and hymns to the Paiwan language, and this began the writing of the Paiwan language.

pwn: pai ka 1945 a cavilj, mangetjez a sinzia a krisito a cioro kiokai a sema toa qinaljan noa sepaiwan a patagilj. ayatoa tjorovo aravac a caocao a masalo, sa meliyaw a isaonioni a liningedjelj a kiokai.
english: Since the year of 1945, believers of the Christian Presbyterian church started to arrive at the Paiwan villages. Because there were very many people who believed, and the church soon grew very fast.

pwn: amin a vecik a pasemalaw toa pasasevalivalit, toa penacalivatan na taqaljaqaljan, a papacon toa natemalido a kakodan noa kacalisiyan, sa tolowan, sa pazorongan. ljakoa neka no vecik toa kai noa kacalisiyan.
english: There is only pattern, with which to tell the changes, the history of fellow villagers, to show the impressive part of the indigenous culture, and its instruction, and its continuance. However, there is no written language for indigenous peoples.

pwn: ljakoa a kacalisiyan i Taiwan, kemasicoai amin a tjaocikel, amin a vecik, a pitoa inalang a kasiw, a qaciljai, katoa vincikan a itong, a inalang a cempo, a vincikan i ta lima.
english: But for indigenous peoples in Taiwan, for a long time, there is only oral story, only pattern as per patterns made on the tree trunk, on the stone, and drawn on clothing, drawn in weaving, written on the hand.

pwn: namasan ljoqes, vavak noa i naqinaljanan. sa a tjakai mavan napakeljangan toa tjakakodakodan a i qinaljan.
english: It [Language] is the essence and soul of a people. Our language is the means through which we present our culture in the indigenous village.

pwn: a kai noa caocao sinipavai noa cemas, a napakisomalji a mangoaqan, tjasipakakeljakeljangan toa tjavarong.
english: Human language is a gift from God, a very special blessing, the means through which we reveal our heart.

pwn: no ini'anga kaminasinasi a caocao a qemozimozip, tjasannamacaiyanga.
english: If a person or an animal is no longer breathing, we think they died already.

pwn: pazangal a coai itjen i ta zaljom a inika minasi.
english: It is difficult for us to stay in the water for a long time and not breathe.

pwn: aico a maqesang a caocao, nakoya a sinasi nimadjo.
english: He or she who has asthma has a weak respitory system.
Nothing is more valuable than our life.
The mountain area is filled with game.

pwn: djoljam aya itjen toa oqaljay no mapana izoa inalap, no magado izoa qinaljop.
english: We call a man a crown hunter if he always catches fish in the river and catches game in the mountain.

pwn: i gadogado a nia omaq. valivali no kaljacoljowan.
english: Our house is on the hill. It is cool in summer.
It's not good to boast about ourselves.

pwn: pakanangoaq amen a mapoljat toa so sikodaan.

english: What are they doing in the chicken farm?

pwn: maya kinemenem toa kitjokoda toa so cekelj.
english: Do not think of leaving your spouse.

pwn: maretimaljimalji a kinakemodan na zoa mareka kisi.
english: Each of those bowls looks different.

pwn: no padjele itjen a pasosangas toa tjakemodanga, nasarongoaq itjen a kiposaliman.
english: If we prepare everything in advance, we will do well.

pwn: kemoda aya no varong to sa sengsengan?
english: What do you think of this issue? (Literally: What does your heard say about this issue?)
Let's reconcile and unite. What's the use of fighthing?
What can we do since you choose so.

pwn: makoda son ko son a qemaoqaong a macidjilj?
english: What happened with you, as you are crying by yourself?

pwn: azoa a ko qali a ti conoq, liyaw aravac a kinljakeljang a patjara tjakakodanan a paiwan.
english: That friend of mine, cunuq, has a lot of knowledge about our Paiwan culture.

pwn: namasankakodananga tjanoitjen a kacalisian a marekiljivak.
english: For us indigenous peoples, love each other is an age-old custom.

pwn: nakoya a macelaqot no karakoda itjen.
english: When we work, do not get lazy.

pwn: avan aico a kasiw a nia sinkezan ka kasimazamen katjaisangas.
english: This tree is the place where we stopped when we came here last time.

pwn: nasanekanga no dinci ko nasemekez sa toki.
english: The clock stops most likely because the battery is out.
Pause and stop; you look tired.

pwn: pasekez tjanoaken azoa kisaco, sa kinsa toa ko siontingting.
english: That police officer stopped me and checked my drivers license.

pwn: aico a tja djalan a paiwan izoa sakamaya sasekezan.
english: For us Paiwan, there is always a place to stop and rest on our road.

pwn: a sisekez ta vencik toa lonbon ni vorovor, masaposaladj tjanoaken.
english: The reason why vuruvur stops writing his dissertation is to help me.

pwn: pai, maya kipaqadilj, sekezan a palamo.
english: Hey, do not force too hard, rest a while.

pwn: ljemiogljiog ti kaka tjai ljegean a pakataqetaqed.
english: Sister is rocking ljegean in the cradle to make the baby girl sleep.

pwn: ljemiog aken ta ko kaka sa ko kelikeli.
english: I put my brother in the cradle and rock the cradle.

pwn: aico a ljiog mavan a tja sipakataqetaqed toa lomalomad.
english: This swing is what we use to put the baby to sleep.

pwn: rovareqon aravac ti solja no nataqed, sa ika sekataqed ta zoma.
english: sulja snores a lot when he sleeps, which makes it hard for other people to sleep.

pwn: cinaqevan noa pariok, ika malangeda toa zaing.
english: The voice covered by the big wok cannot be heard. [Meaning: All voices deserve a chance to be heard.]

pwn: a drokodrokong a tjakit, tjasikasengsengseng, no tja coai, tja radjai, tja galiljgilj.
english: The sickle and knife, those we work with, the longer we use them, the sharper, the shiner. [Meaning: Don't be lazy. Work hard. Practice makes perfect.]

pwn: aza tjinoktjok na tjakenge a kasiw, nekanga a tjengelay.
english: Nobody likes that tree that is pecked by a woodpecker. [Meaning: Be mindful of your honor. Protect your reputation.]

pwn: aza sevesevec a kai, nangoaq a vinarongan.
english: Straightfoward remarks reveal a candid thought. [Meaning: Honesty is the best policy. Honest are those who do not beat around the bushes.]
Dead people do not talk. [Meaning: There is no fire without smoke.]

pwn: no zemaing a takolapang, tjara ori qemodjaljanga. no zemaing a tjakanga, tjara ori macenglaw.
english: When the frog croaks, it is going to rain. When the eagle shouts, the sun will shine. [Meaning: Wisdom from a lived experience of intimate relationship with nature.]

pwn: aza sinavota a nemanga, pazangal a paljacoacoai.
english: That is taken by force does not last. [Meaning: Let nature take its course. Don't be too hard on yourself.] World gloss:

pwn: a vencaveca a kai, madjolo a djomaken.
english: Lies easily give away. [Meaning: Be honest. ]

pwn: palisi a qemav ta djalan na zaljom. lja aico a zaljom, no coaicoaianga, tjara singlit ta djalan nimadjo.
english: It is a taboo to steal the water way. Becasue this water, if after a long time, will always miss its own way. [Meaning: Do unto others as you would have them done unto you. What goes around, comes around.]

pwn: no sevecong toa loni, nangoaq a sema qaoqaoin a kiqilja.
english: When earthquake comes, it is good to hide in the bamboo forests. [Meaning: Be wordly-wise and play safe.]

pwn: no sikamasanlimaljang a qadaw, vilivililjananga a mavesoang aya, tazoa makayanga vaik a qemaljop a oqaljaqaljai, makayanga vaik a qemoma a sikataqaljan.
english: When it is the fifth day, the last day of the taboo as said, at that time men can go hunting, and village people can go to the field.

pwn: no sikamasansimatjelj a qadaw, azoa malada penaljing a kemapalisi ota, lja kiqaong, kisokob toa cemas to nasoljivatj itjen a taqaljaqaljan.
english: On the fourth day, the female priest will to go every house to perform rituals too, she cries for help and worships the god, praying that everyone in the village is healthy and safe.

pwn: tazoa no zemiyaziyan i katjorovoan. izoa mamazangiljan, izoa kalaingan a papapilipiliq toa tjalja valeljeveljan a vavayan, kitekelan a pakalangalj. aico a namaitoco a kakodan no masalotsalot paseketj aya. natemalido aravac.
english: At that time many people are dancing. There are the chief, the villagers They are selecting the fairest woman, who will drink from the linking cup with the chief. This is the way when people celebrate harvest festival. It is so exciting.

pwn: no sikamasantjelo a qadaw, a oqaljaqaljai a vavayavayan, ikapomaya to volongvolong to kakedriyan, savid nakipaqolid a mitong toa kinacalisianan. maqepoqepo izoa na mamazangiljan a kacasavan, parotavatavak a masasenay a maqacovocovong.
english: When it is the third day, whether boys or girls, whether elder or youth, all especially put on the most beautiful traditional clothes. young people gather at the front yard of the chief's house, they sing to each other to compete who has the best lyrics.

pwn: aza sinatjezan a vavayavayan, tiamadjo a matjaljaljak izoa cinavo a sipavai toa kiljivakan na sodjosodjo. aza sikaizoa no sapapoljiva no kaljasalotan, tja marekiljivaljivak, tja marepaqaljaqaljai.
english: Those girls that receive bundles of wood of love, their parents will give the lovers millet dumplings in return of their affection. This is the way of showing affection in the harvest festival, how we love each other, how we respect one another.

pwn: no padjaljon ta kaljasalotan, papoljivak a oqaljaqaljai ta marekasodjo. tiamadjo a oqaljaqaljai qemoyolj ta sasangoaqan saka mezoa sipecongo a kasiw, sa satjezi a pasa toa na sodjo a omaq. aico a namaitoco sinipakacadja a pakeljang toa varong.
english: During the harvest festival, boys express affection to their loved ones. They the boys tie woods that are good for making fire into bundles, and bring the woods to the house of their loved ones. This is the way they indirectly reveal their heart.

pwn: tazoa pipaljing a patjavang toa kavaqoan, votjolj, qavai, vava, mangetjez a malada a kemapalisi a semanenangoaq toa tja cavilj.
english: At that time, we put at the doorway and offer millet, meat, sticky rice, home-brewed wine, the female priest comes to prary and bless the year.

pwn: izoa a tolo na ramaljemaljeng, to penaola toa tja lami a vaqo, ljakinaloljayan, kinazengezengan aravac. aico a tja lami siayang vaqo a tja sinanpazangal a kemasicoaiyan.
english: There is this teaching from the elders, that we should cherish our food millet, the food that we work so hard for, we sweat a lot for This food, millet, has always been very important from the beginning.

pwn: no sikamosalj a qadaw, pomaljimalji, kisokob toa cemas, patjevota toa kavaqoan. no kemesa, inika makaya sedjelj a kavaqoan, ta pacacioyin a sitjaisangas a cavilj a kinivaqo. no inika itjen a pasoso, pinakapalisi, aya a tja ramaljemaljeng.
english: On the second day, we thank and worship god, and harvest millet. When we cook, we can't use new millet only. We mix new with old millet harvested in previous years. If we fail to observe that, we will be punished, so say the elders.

pwn: no kaljasalotan, navenava a picemekeljan, tazoa marekivalavala itjen. no izoa mangetjez i tjanoitjen, tja patekelan ta vinava pinikak, tja sikitj ta qavai a pasedjalo.
english: When it is harvest festival, every family makes wine. During this time, we visit each other. When there are visitors coming to us, we offer them wine, and we cut some sticky rice cakes to entertain them.

pwn: sangasangasan a qadaw, no masalosalot a i qinaljan, i tjomaq a taqaljaqaljan a mapoljat, sa qavaqavai, sa coljocoljo.
english: When it is the first day of celebrating harvest festival in the village, everyone at home is busy with making rice cakes and slaughtering pigs.

pwn: pomaljimalji toa tja cemas ti tjagaraos, satje kanapolami, povaqo toa tja sikavaljot, aya patarevan noa ico a popalisiyan.
english: To thank our God tjagarus, for he has blessed our livelihood with good harvest and millet, so is the meaning of this ritual.

pwn: kasicoaiyan a tja kakodan, no masokivaqo, izoa a tja sinanpazangal a popalisiyan, mavan azoa masalot.
english: Speaking of our ways in the past, when we have harvested millet, there is an important ceremony, that is harvest ceremony.

pwn: ari vaiki a pacon ta iga.
aico a kadjonangan imaza rokaconoq aravac.
english: The land here is quite prone to collapse.

pwn: tima a ori cemonoq toa aico a djeljep?
english: Who is going to collapse this wall?

pwn: azoa gado a tja pacoconan maconoconoq sakamaya.
english: That mountain we are looking at keeps collapsing.

pwn: kamaconoq a gado i palikolikoz toa qinaljan, tjorovo a nasepacevelj.
english: When the mountain behind the village collapsed into a landslide, many were buried alive.

pwn: kaconoqan tasaoni a nia poljoangan ta zoa qodjalj kata vali.
english: Our cowshed was just washed away by landslide caused by rain and wind.

pwn: maconoq a niamadjo a omaq ta loni.
english: Their house collapsed because of earthquake.

pwn: naremekotj a conoq i pasa kavolongan.
english: The landslide in Mount kavulungan is terrible.

pwn: qinceng a mareka nakoyakoya a pakatoa palisi noa malada.
english: Evil spritis are all blocked outside by the sacrificial ritual the priest performs.

pwn: qecengen a zaljom noa caocao, saka masan vacalj.
english: People block the water, and it becomes a deep pool.

pwn: qemeceng a kisaco i sakinting toa inika kacalisiyan.
english: The police stops non-indigenous people at the checkpoint.

pwn: nakoya semandjeli toa zoma a caocao.
english: It is not nice to laugh at other people.
The way you said it is very funny.

pwn: qemoma a sengsengan ni kama. ljemita a qadav masengsengseng sakamaya. qocengelanga ti kama toa sikipaqadavan. metjevenanga a itong toa zengzengan. ljakoa, toco a cavilj liaw a kiniqinoman ni kama a vaqo. djemeli ti kama toa levan.
english: Father makes a living out of farming. He always works every day. Father's skin is tanned and dark. His clothese is wet becaue of sweat. But. this year Father has a great millet harvest. Father laughes with joy.

pwn: nasecogcog toa tolako a sema kalingo a kisia.
english: A train bound for Hualien collided unexpectedly with a truck.

pwn: aico a kikasiw masa mavananga a seman qaqomain.
english: This act of cutting trees is for the purpose of making farm.

pwn: masanliawliaw a tja qinoman a paiwan, ljakoa tjalja namasanparavacan a vaqo.
english: We Paiwan have many agricultural produces, but millet is the most special.

pwn: ari tja posaladj tjai tja vovo a semanqoma.
english: Come let's help Grandpa with farm work.

pwn: ori kiqinoman amen toa djolis toco a qiljas.
english: We will harvest red quinoa this month.

pwn: demangadangas ti kama toa cinpo a dradrakoyan.
english: Father is smoothening the edge of the woven basket.

pwn: salialim ti vovo ta cemepo toa sekam.
english: Grandma is busy weaving straw mat.

pwn: titjen a paiwan, inika palaing ta oqaljayqaljay kata vavayavayan, kicaqoan a mapoljat toa tjemenon.
english: We Paiwan people, regardless of men and women, everyone learns to weave.

pwn: namayatoco a nia kakodan a kemasicoay.
english: Since in the past our custom was like this.

pwn: no izoa a popalisiyan i qinaljan, izoa a qemavaqavay, a venavavava, a cemoljocoljo toa dridri.
english: Where there is a festival in the village, there is making of sticky rice cake, brewing of wine, and roasting of pig.

pwn: no izoa a nia qaljaqalja a kemasi cadja, sipakikadja a nasangoaq a kakanen.
english: When there are our friends visiting from afar, we treat them with delicious food.

pwn: no namalap a cinonan ta sacemel, pavadis ta mamazangiljan, sa paqarot ta marevetjevetjek, sa naljemavak ta taqaljaqaljan.
english: When a hunter has caught game, he offers the chief's portion to the chief, and he gives a part to the custodian of the hunting ground, and he shares his game with fellow villagers.

pwn: aico a kinsan ta odong imaza makan aravac.
english: The noodles cooked here is very delicious.

pwn: sikakan aico a kizing katoa qecap.
english: These spoon and chopsticks are used for eating.

pwn: tison a nakemesa toa tja kenamain?
kanen ni kama azoa sinandjamai ni kina.
english: Dad ate the dishes prepared by mom.

pwn: masan liawliaw a kakanen i soibai.
english: There are many foods in the store.

pwn: kakodan a pakan toa tja pinakasengseng a caocao.
english: It is customary to feed people who work for us.

pwn: makesanga a sinankaiven ni kina. ido, kanianga.
english: Mom has cooked dinner. Come, let's eat.

pwn: paday a kinsa ni kina toa tja kaiven toco.
english: Rice cooked by mother as our dinner tonight. (Mom cooks rice for our dinner tonight.)

pwn: aico a tjangetjang makaya tja kesain, makaya tja qavain ota.
english: This pumpkin, we can cook it, we can also make cake with it.

pwn: vaik aken a kisapoi a sema toa nia ljaqediqedi a kemesakesanga.
english: I am going to get fire from our neighbor who is cooking at the moment.

pwn: kanakemesa to ita vasa katoa vaqo, sikaveto noa tacemekeljan.
english: You only need to cook one taro and one millet, you can feed the entire family.
When you were marrying, I happened to be in Taipei. [I was in Taipei on your wedding day].

pwn: pacengceng izoa kinsa vasa i kakesan.
english: There happens to be taro rice in the kitchen.

pwn: aico a paljaqic avan a kakasengsengan a seman langalj.
english: This farges evodia fruit is the principal [wood] material used to make a linking cup.
This was what I made just now. [This was my most recent work. / I just made this.]

pwn: no pasovililj ta cengelj, ori vaik aken a masengseng toa lalingedan.
english: I will go make the nose-flute in the afternoon.
What is your job now? (What do you do now?)
Who took the place of your work? [Who's your replacement?]
Take turns to look after the patient.

pwn: pinavalitan azoa namapalak dinki na djalan.
english: Those broken streetlights have been replaced.

pwn: ori vaik aken a sema gingo a kivalit toa taidaidai a paiso.
english: I am going to the bank to exchange for 100-dollar bills.

pwn: kilio: napavalit son toa so migami? cekaw: oi, napavalit aken toa vaqoan a migami.
english: kuliu: Have you changed your eye-glasses? cekaw: Yes, I've changed to a new pair of eye-glasses.

pwn: ori semopo aken, sa mayanan a galogo.
english: I want to read, so do not yet make noise.

pwn: ori kivangalj amen toa manges to kedri.
english: We are going to pick a few mangoes.

pwn: navenangalj a nia saviki toco a cavilj.
english: Our betel nut trees have produced fruits this year.

pwn: nekanan no vangalj na aico a kasiw.
english: This tree has not yet fruited.

pwn: kakedrian anan a'en, nakemaizoanan a'en i spongodan.In English:

english: Our toys were many in the past. [We had many toys in the past.]

pwn: semengac a kai nimadjo, namaya ota a kinodan nimadjo.
english: His words are disgusting, the same also with his deeds.

pwn: no izoa nasaqetjo i tjomaq, palisi ti vovo a vavayan toa tjasevalitan.
english: When there is a sick one at home, Grandma prays to our ancestors.

pwn: anema a saqetjoan ni kama i cekaw?
english: What is the illness of Uncle cekaw?
Teacher did not get enough sleep.

pwn: mavilad a sema ta qinaljan niamadjo.
english: He ran away towards his village.

pwn: vaik amen a posao toa qaljaqalja.
english: We are going to see our guests out.

pwn: aico a sinzia pakatoa inoli a kipaparangez toa cemas.
english: Such is a disciple that puts his trust in God in prayer.

pwn: ori ljemengoaq aken toa qezong a kinapalak noa vali nosaoni.
english: I will fix the window that was broken by the wind soon.
It is not good to hurt others.

pwn: mapalak timadjo toa nemanga no mapolaw.
english: He accidentally breaks things when he gets drunk.
Her thoughts are honest and sincere.

pwn: ari vaiki a sema gado a qemaljop.
english: Come, let's go to the mountain to hunt.
It gets harder in the future, keep fighting!
Take care on the road. We will still see each other.
kavulungan, there is nothing like you.

pwn: aico a tolo noa vavolovolongan tjasikamangoaq aravac.
english: These teachings from elders are very good for us.

pwn: sinivai ni kina aico a ko nasi i toa ko pinoaljakan.
english: Mother gave me this life in my birthday.

pwn: natemalido aravac a kinateveteveljan no maljeveq.
english: The meeting at Five-Year Festival is very spectacular.

pwn: migacalj a'en i tja pitjo a milingan no kadjamadjaman.
english: I get up at seven o'clock in the morning.

pwn: izoa a ko tjaljaljak a oqaljay. ti koi a ngadan nimadjo.
english: I have a younger brother. His name is kui.

pwn: kaka aya amen toa tjavolong tjanoamen.
english: We call those older than us ourselves older brother or sister.

pwn: tjamadjolo a karim ta sengsengan i lizok ta i qinaljan.
english: It is easier to find a job in the city than in the village.

pwn: temeljar a qiljas toco a qezemezemetj.

english: She has gone, but she returns.

pwn: ljaljeqel a kadjonangan tasaoni. tekelo ta linalja.
english: It is very cold today. Drink warm water.

pwn: vaik aken a veneli ta pok, vorasi, vasa, vaqo katoa votjolj.
english: I am going to buy piegon pea, sweet potato, taro, millet and meat.

pwn: toco tjorovoanga a kakedrian a sekacalisian sinipoaljak sa oqacanga i lizok.
english: Now, there are already many indigenous children born and growing up in the city.

pwn: kicaovo ta kaitongan aya ti kina, ayatoa ljaljeqel aravac.
english: Mom said tuck in the blanket because it's quite cold.

pwn: yedda: anema a ico? kina naloko: aico? kosota. yedda: nima a ico a kosota? kina naloko: malji na nison? neka a so paqenetj? yedda: nia'en? neka a ko paqenetj. kina naloko: na nison a ico, apen.
english: Yedda: What's this? Mom Naluku: This? Socks. Yedda: Whose socks? Mom Naluku: Aren't they yours? Don't you remember? Yedda: No, I don't remember. Mom Naluku: They're yours, my girl.

pwn: nakoya inika itjen a pasoso toa siontinting a kakodan, maqalovo a tja djalan.
english: It's not good to not follow traffic regulations, our traffic will become chaotic.

pwn: paolan to napolami itjen toco a cavilj.
english: have pity on us so that we have a great harvest this year.

pwn: notiyaw kiljavaran ti congtong toa taqaljaqaljan.
english: Tomorrow the President will speak to the people.

pwn: ljaljeqel aravac toco a qadaw. 'emoba aken no sema casaw.
english: Today is very cold. I put on a coat when going out.

pwn: aico a kinsan ta soba imaza makan aravac.
english: The noodles cooked here is very delicious.

pwn: a koini mavan natjaljakiljaljavan na paiwan i lizok.
english: Chinese New Year is what Paiwan living in the city look most forward to.
Do not push too hard, rest for a while.

pwn: poqolo aravac timadjo, macaqo toa masan liawaliaw a kai.
english: She is very smart, she can say many languages.

pwn: maljimalji a so papolevan toa tja kinacemekeljan.
english: Thank you for brining honor to our family.

pwn: tja pasedjaloin a qaliqali no mangetjez a sema toa tja qinaljan.
english: When foreigners come to our village, we give them a warm welcome.

pwn: paljakev a kinkina koka toa kiakiav no izoa kowa.
english: When there is an egale, Mother hen protects the chick.
Be careful of the dangerous part of the land.

pwn: pai, ari vaiki a kivangavang. masepelj itjen.
english: Hey, let's go have some fun. I feel bored.

pwn: tjengelay aken a pacon ta iga i ta tilibi.
english: I like to watch moives in the TV.

pwn: a 'namaroqo a vali' mavan a 'mezangal a vali' i pasa paliljaliljaw, aya ti kina.
english: Mom said in Heng-chung peninsula 'the rolling winds' is 'the strong winds'. [That is, the downslope winds orLou-san feng in Chinese, which is especially strong in winter and spring.]

pwn: ako kodrakodral a ko tjiyalj mato namavonglay, sa macidicidilj aken.
english: Why is my belly so big, as if I were pregnant, while I am single.
Let's work together, what's the use of fighting?

pwn: semoqelam aravac a qiljiqilji a caocao.
english: Selfish people are quite a disgust.

pwn: posepi aken a kaseparia toa siking ta daigako.
english: I was lucky to have passed the extam to the university.

pwn: inika maqati a mekelj aken, namangilo aravac a ko coqelalj.
english: I can't run anymore, I feel quite sore all over my bones.

pwn: kolio: anema a so kinasaljingan? idis: mavan a magado a ko kinasaljingan. anema a so kinatjengelayan? kolio: tjalja tjengelay aken a semasing.
english: kuliu: What's your hobby? idis: I like to go hiking. What's your hobby? kuliu: I like photography the most.

pwn: titjen a paiwan izoa a tja kakodan a seman maqacovocovong.
english: We Paiwan have our own rites of passage.

pwn: qacovonganga a so sinipavai tjaoaken a paiso.
english: The money you gave me is already enough.

pwn: mirava timadjo sa vaik a zemian.
english: She dresses up and goes out to dance.

pwn: titjen a caocao kemeljang itjen to neka no tja verican ta caocao.
english: We human beings we know what we should not abandon people.

pwn: izoa a ko siking toa rinipongan toco a qadaw. pida a ko tinso toa ko kinasikingan?
english: I took a Japanese language test today. What is my test score?

pwn: pilima a pasosangas ta keman. poljaten a keman na tjinaljek ata djamai i tjapaq. menoremor no ma a kan. posaladj anan a semenaw ta tjapaq ata qecap.
english: Wash hands before eating. Finish the rice and vegetables in the bowl. Rinse mouth after eating. Also help with washing the bowls and chopsticks.

pwn: aico a sala tja papizoanan toa djamai.
english: We put vegetables in a plate.
What did you put in the wok? What are you cooking in the pan?

pwn: masan mosalj a tja palisian a kacalisian. izoa kakodan a paka toa tja nasi a caocao, izoa kakodan noa taqaljaqaljan a paka toa tja siqoman, tja sikasaloan toa tja vovo. masalot itjen a ljemita a cavilj, maljeveq itjen no lima a cavilj. a tja kemodanga, a tja sepi, a tja qimang a caocao, sinipakicikel noa tja vovo aya itjen.
english: Indigenous rituals are of two kinds. There is one kind for the business of our individual life as human, and there is another kind for the business of the people as a whole like farming or worshipping elders. We celebrate the harvest festival every year, and we celebrate the Five-year Ritual every five years. As we say, everything that we have, our dreams, and our good fortune in life are all given by our elders.

pwn: a kakedrian i kacalisian, no pasa maqacovong a cavilj, sidjaolj toa polingaw sa pokakodani a paceqeljap noa ramaljemaljeng. sipadjolo a oqaljai toa torivecan sa kapalisi a semo ciloq noa polingaw. no katiaw anga, kacoin noa parakaljai a sema pararovo i qaljoqaljopan sa paqayam a qemaljop. a vavayan inika pokakodanan toa qemaljop. kapalisian a papoloqem noa polingaw. ao no makaya anga, kicon toa sicoljoan ta dridri a qadaw sa qacovongi a kakodan noa patjelingaw.
english: When aboriginal children are entering adulthood, the woman priest will bring them to elders who will teach them courage. Boys will be given simple tools, which will be blessed by the woman priest. The next day, the male priest will bring them to the hunting place for them to try hunting. Girls do not have business as hunting. The woman priest will pray to give them courage. When it is done, girls will be see the slaughter of the pig on one day and that concludes the ceremony of everlasting wisdom.

pwn: no qemotjo son i qayaw ta ramaljemaljeng, velio ta vava.
english: If you fart in front of elders, you must buy wine.

pwn: kasicoaian palisi a poaljak toa qidar.
english: In the past, giving birth to twins was a taboo.

pwn: palisi a keman ta padai kasicoaian.
english: In the past, it was a taboo to eat rice.

pwn: titjen a paiwan, pinaka palisi aravac a kipacai.
english: For us Paiwan, suicide is regarded as a big taboo.

pwn: toco a qadaw avan a ko kinaqatian a qadaw. napinadjolo tjanoamen ni kina toa liawliaw a kakanen a kaiv. ozai a ciqaw, djorikoko, gang, qozang, djamai ata veljevelj. sangoaq aravac to mapoingyang ota. maljelima amen i ta taqomaqanan. ozai ti vovo oqaljay, ti vovo vavayan, ti kama, ti kina, ata ti aken. malevaleva amen a mapoljat.
english: Today is my birthday. Mom prepared a lot of food for us to eat at dinner There are fish, chicken, crab, shrimp, vegetable and banana. They are very delicious and nutritious. We have five in the family. They are grandpa, grandma, dad, mom, and I myself. Everyonf of the family is very happy.

pwn: tjakodain no papeliaw a ko paiso?
english: What shall I do if I want to multiply my money?

pwn: titjen a paiwan, mamaw a ligo noa djemameq toa qaris katoa comai.
english: For us Paiwan, catching an eagle is as honorable as catching a bear.

pwn: no kaljapalisian, mitong itjen ta kinacalisianan a taqaljaqaljan.
english: When it's a festival, we the village people wear traditional clothes.

pwn: ngoangoaq aravac a kinasengseng ta qatataqa a itong a pinaiwanan.
english: The Paiwan traditional clothes made of beads are very pretty.

pwn: kasicoaian, aico a mamazangiljan napaljavak toa pana, cemecemel, qinaljan katoa taqaljaqaljan.
english: In the past, the chief's sphere of power or influence covered the river, forest, village and people.

pwn: toco masanliawliawanga tjasipavaivai a kazeljo toa siho.
english: Now the tax, that we give to the government, is getting higher and higher.

pwn: izoa namasanliawliaw a vadis noa paiwan.
english: Paiwan people have many types of tax.

pwn: vaik aken a sema yocy a zemololj ta valjitjoq.
english: I am going to the post office to deposit money.

pwn: coai a vengin. sao, vaiko a taqed.
kolio: pida a milingan toco? idis: tapoloq saka ita a milingan toco.
english: kuliu: What time is it now? idis: It's eleven o'clock now.

pwn: vaik son notiyaw a kivava ta povaljawvaljaw? vaik son notiyaw a kidjamai toa pocekecekelj?
english: Are you going to the wedding tomorrow?
How much do you earn every day? (What's your daily wage?)
I am a descendant of Paiwan.

pwn: aico mavan a tja sinicipilj tjai vovo.
english: This is what we prepare for Grandma's passing.

pwn: masanlialiaw a tja qinoman a paiwan, ljakoa tjalja namasanparavacan a vaqo.
english: We Paiwan have many crops, but millet has been the most precious among them.

pwn: sisocipilj itjen ta vaqoan a itong.
english: We prepare new clothes for the person marrying into our family.
Do not give your love without thinking.

pwn: i kavolongan a kiniveqacan noa paiwan.
english: The origin of Paiwan is in Mount kavulungan.

pwn: namakoda a kinaqadavan toco a qadaw?
no vaik itjen ta gado, kacoi ta rokorokong a ikasiw.
english: When we go to the mountains, bring the sickle to chop down trees.

pwn: i vavavavaw ta kasiw a viyar, ljakoa i tekoteko ta namacemo a kasiw a ljoyljoy.
english: viyarsit on the upper part of on the tree, butljuyljuysit on the lower part of rotten trees.
It's all right; try again next time.
How is it with your family?

pwn: liav aravac a tjaocikel ni vovo a patjara tjakakodanan noa paiwan kasicoayan.
english: Grandma has a lot of stories about our Paiwan culture and customs in the past.

pwn: kacalisian aya itjen a paiwan toa kaimazanga a mareka caocao.
english: We Paiwan call each people that has been here [indigenous peoples] the hill peoples.

pwn: aico a kadjonangan namasan zaisang noa paiwan.
english: This land is the property of Paiwan.

pwn: pairang aya itjen a paiwan toa kasoso noa gaisiyodjing.
english: We Paiwan call Minnan the relatives of Chinese mainlanders.

pwn: neka no miqaqili toa zian noa paiwan.
english: There is no swaying hips in the dance of Paiwan.

pwn: no cemoljo itjen toa qacang no masodjosodjo, tja sivai toa mamazangiljan a qacai.
english: When we slaughter a pig at wedding, liver is what we offer to the chief.

pwn: kolio: makoda son, idis? idis: saqetjo a ko vicoka.
english: kuliu: What happened, idis? idis: My stomach hurts.

pwn: no semekez a tja qavovong, macai itjen a pakazoazoa.
english: If our heart stops, we will die immediately.
Do not smoke too much; our lungs will get sick.
I like to keep you company.
Why is your clothes stained all over with blood?

pwn: nakoya a pacalivat ta masengseng, mangilo a tjakinacavacavan.
english: Do not overwork, our body will get tied.

pwn: "polingalingav itjen ta zoa so kai, ljakoa ika tjen na'ivo'ivo maitazoa."
english: "We understand what you are saying, but we didn't talk like that."

pwn: aico a toto noa kina maro sicevodanga noa nasi na qonoqono.
english: These breasts of a mother are like the spring of life of an infant.

pwn: nia kasoso a zoa mamazangiljan i padain.
english: Our relative is that chief at padain.

pwn: namasanpazangal aravac a qacang i ta papocekecekelj.
english: Pig is very important in the wedding.
We had many enemies in the past.
We all close doors in the evening.

pwn: pida a kakavelian na aico a kaljat?
english: What's the price of this glazed-bead bracelet?

pwn: izoa namakaizoazoa a qemozimozip i pokasivan.
english: There are all kinds of animal in the forest.

pwn: kasicoayan, no patagilj a mimaqacovongan a oqaljai a vavayan, maqatianga a povaljaw.
english: In the past, when boys and girls are turning adolescents, they can get married already.

pwn: izoa liaw a patarevan no ljemavaran tia paiwan.
english: There are many metaphors when Paiwan people instruct.

pwn: olja so pinivarong sakamaya a kai ni vovo.
english: Hope the words of elders are still kept in your heart.

pwn: timitja se-ka-calisi-an avan na-tja-maoram toa paiso a caocao. amin na-paka toa qaozeqez a z<em>ololj toa paiso a kakodan, maqati a se-tjo-koda toa paolaolan.
english: We indigenous peoples are economically disadvantaged people. Only by the habit of thrift and money-saving, are we able to break away from poverty.

pwn: lima a inaqadavan a tja masalot.
english: Our festival runs for five days.

pwn: matjaonem a qinaljan imaza i toa nia kinagoan a sinvaodjan.
english: There are six villages here in our townshipsinvaudjan.

pwn: izoa a paqolid a likoljaw i maza i ta gado?
english: Are there really clouded leopards here in this mountain?

pwn: tjevetjeveng a ico a kadjonangan imaza.
a lapo toa nametad a itong.
titjen a paiwan neka no kakodan ta semancabokan.
english: We Paiwan do not practice slavery (according to Masegseg Zengror Gadu).

pwn: a ico a silji izoa laroaroq, izoa liporoporo.
english: Some peppers are long, some peppers are round.

pwn: namasanpazangal aravac a vaqo i kacalisian.
english: Millet is very important in indigenous villages.

pwn: nadjemameq toa comai ti vovo sapai.
pokasivan aravac a zoa i kavolongan.
english: Mount kavulungan is full of prime forest.

pwn: ari a mapoljat senasenai, ari a mapoljat zianziani. ari a mapoljat kivangavangi, ari a mapoljat ljakaljakai.
english: Let's sing. Let all of us dance. Everybody, come play. Come, everybody, let's play swing.

pwn: navaik aken a sema koto hoing toco a qadaw.
english: I went to the High Court today.

pwn: aico a likisi tjasikeljangan toa patjarapinacalivatan noa tja sevalitan, noa tja qinaljan, katoa tja nasi a caocao.
english: History makes us know better about the past of our ancestors, our village, and our human life.

pwn: sa titjen a se paiwan nadjemaljon toa 102,931 a caocao.
english: And we Paiwan have reached a population of 102,391.

pwn: no ori kisodjo son, nakoya kicakaw.
english: If you want to fall in love, it is not good to hide.

pwn: aljak na kacalisian i taiwan aken. qocengecengelj aken ota, ljakoa inika aken a semanvililj toa kama tedros. maya pasekapalak toa kacaoan, oi, kama tedros. kivalavalaoanga a sema toa nia qinaljan i taiwan. masalo.
english: I am a child of Paiwan in Taiwan. My skin is dark too, but I didn't accuse Director-General Tedros [of being a nigger]. Please do not mislead the world, DG Tedros. Come to visit our village in Taiwan. Thank you. Glossary: aljak: childka-calisi-an: indigenous people or Paiwan. The root iscalisi'hill'.qu-cenge-cengelj: black. The root isqucengelj'dark, black' in reduplication.inika: did notseman-vililj: to slight or accuse. The root isvililj'behind, after'.kama: father or eldermaya: do not, prohibitionpa-se-ka-palak: confuse or mislead. The root ispalak'damage, break'.kacauan: the world, the earth, where people arekivala-vala-anga: invite to come and visit. The root iskivala'visit'; -anga'change of state '.nia: our, 1st person plural genitive qinaljan: village

pwn: izoa a ko qesang. marekotj aken toa ljayar.
english: I have phlegm. I am afraid of the flu.

pwn: izoa malje onem a polingaw i tjovecekadan.
english: In tjuvecekan village, there are six priests.

pwn: liaw a so paiso i ta gingko?
english: Do you have a lot of money in the bank?
I feel tired, then I feel lazy.

pwn: izoa kaljavevean, kaljacoljowan, kaljaoraman, kaljaljeqelan a i ta cavilj. tja tjengelay aken toa kaljaljeqelan, ayatoa i ta kaljaljeqelan a ko sinipoaljakan.
english: There are spring, summer, fall, winter in an year. I like winter better because my birthday is in winter.

pwn: nasaljinga aken to nasoljivatj, natarivak, saka namaleva mon a mapoljat.
english: I wish peace, health, and happiness to you and all.

pwn: nakemasi tairiko aico a saqetjoan na va. mapovarong a caocao to masepo. kiqobeso saka pilimao.
english: This disease of the lungs comes from China. People are worried about infection. Wear mask and wash hands.

pwn: maledepanga a qadaw, miselemananga a kadjonangan. miselemananga a kadjonangan, zemaing a tjikililj. zemaing a tjikililj, mineqot a qiljas. mineqot a qiljas, paceged a ljeqo.
english: As the sun sets, it becomes dark on earth. As it darkens on earth, crickets start to sing. As crickets sing, the moon shows her face. As the moon appears, the Owl wakes up.

pwn: inika amin a tjengelay; romedananga aken tjanoson a ko varong.
english: I do not just "Like you" only; my heart is already broken into pieces for you.

pwn: a namivavavan a caocao kidjadjalanan noa siniaqan; a namitatekoan a caocao dinatar noa povarongan.
english: Proud people are followed by shame; humble people have wisdom as company.

pwn: no zemaing a ceqer, qemodjalj; no zemaing a kowa, macengelaw.
english: If the frog croaks, it rains; if the vulture calls, it shines.

pwn: kemoda itjen a posaladj toa FormosanBank?
tjara ljemaoi a so zirio maqati a pavai toa kindri pasoso ta CC-BY-NC a holic (amilikan|ciniokokan) sa sicekaw itoa wanglo.
english: You must agree for your data to be published with the open-source license CC-BY-NC (English | Chinese).

pwn: no saljinga son a cemekaw emaya toa malji mon a kindri parotoa open-soorce ayaya, maqati a mazepzep katoa ringrako tjanoamen.
english: If you prefer a different open-source license, please discuss with us.

pwn: kemoda timadjo a cemekaw toa nison a zirio?
english: What can people do with your data?

pwn: tjara pasoso toa kakodan noa FormosanBank no macekaw toa zirio:
english: Anyone can use data in FormosanBank for any purpose, with the following restrictions:

pwn: timaimanga dikinay a paveli toa so zirio.
neka a maqati a paveli toa masan nison a zirio ta AI.
english: Nobody can sell artificial intelligence trained using your data.

pwn: tjara kiteko katoa pakeljang toa so kindri noa zirio a timaimanga no macekaw toa so zirio.
english: Anyone who uses your data must acknowledge your work.

pwn: tjara nopasoso toa mareka kakodan, timaimanga maqati a cemekaw toa so zirio itoa:
english: As long as they follow those rules, anyone may use your data for:

pwn: izoa kisanvenecik saljinga to macekaw seman siobai a sengsengan. nosaljinga son to maqati masan siobay a so sengsengan, tjomalji amen.
english: Some authors wish to allow for commercial uses. If you wish to allow commercial uses, please discuss with us.

pwn: tison avananga izoa a kindri pakatoa so zirio sakamaya.
english: You remain the author and owner of your data.

pwn: a FormosanBank tjara kiteko to tison angata poanema.
english: acknowledge you as the author and owner of your data.

pwn: timaimanga no cemekaw toa so zirio tjara kiteko to nison a pokindri.
english: Anyone who uses your data must acknowledge you as the author and owner of the data.

pwn: amin son maqati a paveli ta so tjinaocikel a caocao.
english: You remain the only person who can sell your data.

pwn: anema pasosoan? kemoda itjen a pakakoda?
english: What is the process? How does this work?

pwn: tjara nia kivadaqan son toa pakata so tjaocikel kata kemoda cemikilo toa mareka so vinarongan to oli tja kodai. aico palemek izoa:
english: We discuss your data with you, along with any constraints you have. These may include:

pwn: maqati amen a posaladj toa maqilja mareka vavecikan itoa so zirio. maqati amen a kemaljava itoa tiningco a zikang a pekeljang a posaladj qemayam kemin sa semangoaq ta pasaliw itoa tjaocikel.
english: We can help anonymize some part of the data. We can wait to publish the data until after a specific date. We can help look for and fix mistakes in the data.

pwn: saljinga son to aza na sacemekaw ta zirio pacacolo kata so wanglo? toki saljinga tiamadjo dikilo a kipakim toa so mareka lonbon?
english: You decide how you want your work to be acknowledged. Should users link to your website? Should they cite a paper of yours?

pwn: oli mapavalit toa so zirio itoa namaljaloay a vinecikan.
english: We convert the data into FormosanBank format.

pwn: tjara nia kigaljoi a qemayam a so zirio, mapaqolid to neka pasaliw. no po'oi son, maqati son a ljemizaw toa so tjaocikel.
english: We carefully check the data to make sure there are no errors. If you wish, you can also review the data.

pwn: tjara nia sinan pazangal a so zirio masanitalj itoa FormosanBank sa mazepzep a patjomalj.
english: We publish the data as part of FormosanBank.

pwn: avansika namaitoco a kai pakatoa nia sengsengan. napaljakev toa so mangoaqan, sa tjara mapasoso toa so vinarongan.
english: This ensures your data is shared with the world in a way that aligns with your wishes and protects your rights.

pwn: tja kipapawlingaven a cekaw toa zirio imaza
maqati a malaing a macekaw sa sicekaokao toa zirio itoa FormosanBank, ljakoa izoa matjapida a tjara oli tja sikinemenem.
english: You are free to use and redistribute FormosanBank materials subject to the following restrictions:

pwn: maya sinan paveli namaya toa AI a sengsengan
aza zirio a penoljat itoa FormosanBank maqati a macekaw itoa mareka sengsengan patjara vaqoan a kikay, pakicaqoan, semeking katoa zoma seman AI a kikay a kalakodaing.
english: The corpora of FormosanBank, or any derivative works thereof, may not be used, in whole or in part, for the development, training, testing, or deployment of artificial intelligence systems, algorithms, or models intended for commercial purposes.

pwn: ljakoa dikinay a macekaw taico a zirio itoa seman siobay a sengsengan katoa nalemingdjelj toa mamaw a pinitoa ziriokan itoa wanglo.
english: This includes, but not limited to, technologies designed to generate text for commercial purposes or capable of creating works in the same style or genre as the corpus.

pwn: a isangas a sinipakeljang anga a zirio kemasi toa kakaizoanan i wanglo. avansika tjara venecik toa kinaizoanan no macekaw taico a zirio. ayatoa pasoso toa kakodan katoa mareka holic toco, kipapovarong a venecik ta sekeljang a kinaizoanan, ljakoa no neka no vecik pakatoa kinaizoanan, maqati anan venecik ta FormosanBank maitoco a vecik.
english: Most of the corpora are derived from a previously-published source. To use them, you may need to cite the source material. Required citations on listed on the page for each corpus in the manual and also in the root of each XML file. If there is no required citation listed, this means it is sufficient to cite FormosanBank itself, as described below. Where the source material is public domain, you are not legally required to cite the source but you should as common courtesy.

pwn: kipapaolingavo aza kindri pakatoa macekaw taico a zirio, sika pacono ljemita vinecikan itoa qadopo katoa pino i XML a pakeljang.
english: Note that for many of the corpora, the license includes additional restrictions such as allowing only non-commercial use. The license for the source material is described on the corpus page in the manual for each corpus, as well as in the root of every XML file.

english: FormosanBank annotations and metadata are CC-BY-4.0. This means you must cite the source in any redistributed or derived products. For code packages, you may refer to the GitHub repository. For academic publications, you should cite:

pwn: masalo toa mareka caocao katoa kinateveteveljan itoa aico a venkatj na pavai toa caqoan na kai, otaota a vinarongan itoa tja seqetjen a kemacalisian. no neka no namaitoco a posaladjan niamadjo, inika soljivat a maqacovong sakamaya.
english: We are deeply indebted to the many individuals and organizations who have supported the Formosan Bank project. This initiative would not have been possible without their dedication, expertise, and unwavering commitment to preserving the rich linguistic heritage of the Formosan languages.

pwn: kinateveteveljan noa qinepenepoan toa valjicoq ta sipapilazekan a cemokicok toa kai noa kacalisian
english: Indigenous Languages Research and Development Foundation

pwn: masalo toa kinateveteveljan a pavai toa zirio namaitoco a pazangal a vinecikan pakatoa kemacalisian. avansika tiamen na venkatj maqati a ljevavaw toa nia sengsengan pakatoa seman taico a FormosaBank a qinepoqepo a pinitoaziriokan.
english: We are immensely grateful to the Indigenous Languages Research and Development Foundation, based in Taipei, Taiwan, for their invaluable contribution. ILRDF has generously shared their extensive data on Formosan languages with us, enabling our team to push forward in creating a comprehensive, machine-readable corpus. We owe much of our progress to their partnership.

pwn: masalo ota toa zoma a sinsi katoa sitjaracaqoan a kai a caocao:
english: The following have contributed data to FormosanBank. Note that in some cases, the data is still being processed and not yet publicly available.

pwn: masalo ota toa kikingkai pinaka NSF kemasi Amilika. na ljemaoi a pavai ta paiso sa papopicol toa aico a venkatj. avansika namasan pazangal a maqepoqepo a tja kinatevteveljan a milazek katoa kiroko taico a kemacalisian.
english: We are also grateful for the financial support provided by the National Science Foundation through award #2319296. This grant has been crucial in enabling us to undertake such an ambitious project, and it reaffirms the importance of our collective efforts in revitalizing and preserving endangered languages.

pwn: a FormosanBank mavan a qepoqepoan a ziting sa pinitoaziriokan, napapeliaw itoa i wanglo a vecik kata lemoing pakatoa kemacalisian setaiwan.
english: FormosanBank serves as a centralized repository for linguistic data across the 16 extant Formosan languages.

pwn: olja na madjolo a kidjomak toa mareka milimilingan a sitjaracaqoan ta kai, sinsi katoa maretimalji a kacalisian i Taiwan. saka papilazek teveljeng a kinkiw, tatoloan katoa paljazoa a sengsengan.
english: The project aims to make these resources easily accessible for researchers, educators, and indigenous community members to facilitate research, education, and language preservation efforts.

pwn: aico a pakatoa zirio sedjelj a:
english: The materials in the corpus include:

pwn: sivecikan katoa venecik:izoa vecikan, lemoing, ziting katoa kakaiyan pasata i tingnaw.
english: Texts and Transcriptions: Digitized texts, transcribed audio, dictionaries, and reference grammars.

pwn: zirio pakatoa lemoing: izoa maretimalji a tjaocikel, paro toa sinbong sekacalisian, kamoko itoa tilibi, milimilingan katoa matjatjaocikel. avansika izoa namakakaizoazoa a kinakaikaian katoa tjemaocikel a caocao.
english: Audio Recordings: A range of spoken language materials, such as Indigenous news, talk shows, traditional stories, and interviews, covering diverse dialects and speaker demographics.

pwn: kaisiako pakatoa vincikan: naljemaloay a kinaisiako itoa kai a caqoan, paro toa piniliq a vecik, lemoing sa piliqi katoa valiti a zaing a venecik katoa liaw a kakaiyan a kaisiako.
english: Annotated Corpora: Detailed linguistic annotations including word-level glosses, morpheme-level segmentation, phonological transcriptions, and translations in multiple languages.

pwn: nakidjomadjomak anan toa milimilingan toco a nia sengsengan. namaya toa ziting, a vinecikan itoa likisi, a sibong na sekacalisian katoa mareka sonatj.
english: Data collection is ongoing and encompasses a wide array of sources, such as dictionaries, historical documents, Indigenous media, and academic publications.

pwn: otaota izoanan noa moqamian katoa pinaiwanan itoa YooTobe, kamoko na sekacalisan, remadadingki a qadopo, kinkiw a sonatj. (tja paconan ta zirio pakamaza).
english: The corpora currently being processed include materials like Amis and Paiwan YouTube videos, Indigenous talk shows, eBooks, and academic texts (see the current list of corpora here).

pwn: aza FormosanBank liningdjelj paka tingnaw itoa i Pangloss Collection, avansika naseljengoaq katoa namadjolo a semeqetj toa kakaiyan. lja aico a sengsengan, maljaloay a pacon ta penoljat a vinecikan katoa ljemita a vecik, otaota maqati a sicekaw itoa kinkiw katoa mareka sengsengan itoa tingnaw ljaki matjatjaovalit ta kai, ljaki kitolo ta lemoing.
english: FormosanBank uses a standardized XML format developed by the Pangloss Collection to ensure consistency across the corpus. This format organizes data hierarchically, representing texts, sentences, words, and morphemes, with each level annotated as needed. The structure allows for optional elements like translations and audio references, making the data suitable for both linguistic analysis and computational processing.

pwn: aico a namaljaloay a vinecikan izoanan mareka zirio italadj, sedjelj a sipakeljang toa namakoda a sicekaw itoa zoma a kinaizoanan, kineljangan a zirio, banggo nia kai, avansika namakeljang to paqolid a vinecikan.
english: The format includes attributes for essential metadata, such as citations, copyright information, and language codes, ensuring transparency and proper attribution.

pwn: otaota namaljengoaq a paseljavak, kinkiw sa matevelj katoa mareka sitjaracaqoan a kakaiyan a sengsengan.
english: By adopting a consistent format, FormosanBank facilitates data sharing, analysis, and integration with other linguistic tools.

pwn: a zirio seFormasanBank a penoljat namasi ta kindri a pomacidilj katoa holic pakatoa namakoda pavai ta kindri a djemomak pasaino.
english: Each resource in FormosanBank has its own copyright and licensing terms, with most materials made available under Creative Commons licenses to encourage reuse and sharing.

pwn: avansika oli papopicol toa sipoita anan a macekaw katoa paseljavak noa timaimanga.
english: Licensing details, including copyright holders and usage restrictions, are provided on the individual resource pages.

pwn: lja aico a sengsengan namasan pazangal aravac to kiljivak toa aico a zirio pakamaza katoa seman pazangal to kindri nasesaozayan a caqoan a caocao.
english: This ensures transparency and respect for intellectual property rights while making the data as accessible as possible.

english: FormosanBank's resources are organized to support both linguistic analysis and community use. The data is structured with:

pwn: madjolo a kidjomak ta zirio italadj, izoa kakaiyan, kinakaikaian, siqelaqelan na lemoing kata kaisiako a kinaizoanan.
english: Metadata for easy search and retrieval, including language, dialect, speaker information, and source details.

pwn: pagaogao ta API katoa malap ta qinepo a kakaiyan zirio, lja ljemangoaq a semopo kinkiw masengseng patjara sa qepoing toa maljetimalji a torivecan.
english: APIs and downloadable datasets to facilitate computational research and integration with other tools.

pwn: aza tja kinkiwin maqati a venecik itoa ljemita tadalj a zirio itoa FormosanBank, avansika inika amin a kiroko taico a kinacaisian, izoanan a posaladj a ljevavaw a semangoaq taico a kinkiw a sengsengan patjara kai katoa tingnaw.
english: The format's flexibility also allows researchers to annotate data at different levels of granularity, making FormosanBank a valuable resource for projects ranging from basic language documentation to advanced natural language processing.

pwn: inika amin a kinkiw sinan torivecan itoa wanglo, aico a FormosanBank tjara sinan pazangal aravac a pavai toa liaw a picol a kicapilj toa mareka kalakodaing:
english: FormosanBank is more than a research tool; it plays a crucial role in revitalizing endangered Formosan languages. By providing a well-organized and accessible collection of linguistic resources, FormosanBank supports:

pwn: pinenetjan itoa kinitoloan: ayatoa seman liaw a vinecikan katoa caqoan a zirio, sa maqati a macekaw itoa gakko katoa qinaljan sakamaya.
english: Educational initiatives: Creating teaching materials and learning resources for use in schools and community programs.

pwn: a venkatj pakatoa kiroko noa sikataqaljan: posaladj toa sikataqaljan a lemoing kata semeqetj toa niamadjo a kakaiyan.
english: Community-driven documentation projects: Assisting local communities in recording and preserving their languages.

pwn: seman vaqoan ta torivecan itoa tingnaw: namaljengoaq a sengsengan patjara kai a kinkiw. paro kemeljang toa zaing, tjatjaovalit ta kai pasata zoma a kakaiyan katoa kikay sitjaracaqoan a kitolo toa kai itoa tingnaw.
english: Digital tool development: Enabling the creation of language technologies like speech recognition, machine translation, and language learning apps.

pwn: aico a venkatj nakigetjem a papilazek, venkatj to papeliaw ta kakaiyan, paljevavaw a semangoaq ota.
english: The project is continually evolving, with plans to expand the corpus, improve data quality, and incorporate new technologies for linguistic research.

pwn: lja izoa kacalisian, sitjaracaqoan ta kakaiyan katoa sinsi a matevelj a posaladj, tjara sinan tjaqayaw a pinovarong toa kiljivak toa sikataqaljan sa paljazoa toa tja cinalivatan i palingolingolj.
english: Collaboration with Indigenous communities, linguists, and technology experts remains a key component of FormosanBank's growth, ensuring that the project remains community-oriented and culturally sensitive.

pwn: aza kemacalisian i Taiwan sedjelj a senantaw a kakaiyan, tjalja qacavan sa nasepolingetj i kacaoan a kadjonangan, senantaw a kakaiyan na kemasi kaledep a "Madagascar" pasa kacedas a "Easter Island," mavan imaza i Taiwan sinan kakaiyan noa senantaw a kiniveqacan.
english: The Formosan languages belong to the Austronesian language family, one of the world's largest and most geographically widespread language groups. While the Austronesian languages extend from Madagascar in the west to Easter Island in the east, Taiwan is home to a significant number of unique languages within this family. These languages are collectively known as the Formosan languages.

pwn: seladenga itjen to aza nantaw zoko patagilj a kaimaza i Taiwan izoanga 6,000 a cavilj, avansika sipazorong toa namakakaizoazoa sa maretimalji a kemacalisian imaza.
english: The Austronesian-speaking people are believed to have first settled in Taiwan around 6,000 years ago, making it one of the earliest regions to develop distinct Austronesian languages.

pwn: ka i tjaisangas ta nantaw zoko na ljesasaw a patjavat i tjozoma kadjonangan, i Taiwan avananga novecekadakadan patjara kai katoa bongka, avansika namasi coacoayan a cinalivatan katoa likisi imaza.
english: The diversity among the Formosan languages is a testament to this long history, as the island served as a hub of linguistic evolution and cultural exchange before the Austronesian people began migrating to other parts of Southeast Asia and the Pacific.

pwn: tocoanga, lja izoa tapoloq sa onem a kemacalisian i Taiwan a pinenetj na siho itoa holic, ljakoa a milazekan macacadja anan. toco a senantaw a kakaiyan amin namapoljo a kacalisian a cemekaokaw, aico a mareka kacalisian kimaya noa i Taiwan 2% a caocao, avansika liaw a kakaiyan na senataw itoa oli maqoip saka abonay, kimaya mapoljo a caocao a qivo itoa sikavaljotan i qinaljan. avansika oli kemedreng a kiroko sa paljazoa a kemacalisian itoa tja sengsengan. olja ca kakaiyan maqati anan a maseqetj no tjaivilivililj.
english: Today, there are 16 officially recognized Formosan languages, though their vitality varies greatly. Formosan languages today are spoken only by a portion of Taiwan's indigenous population, constituting ~2% of Taiwan's population. Therefore, many of these languages are considered endangered, with only a few actively spoken in daily life. The speakers often reside in specific Indigenous communities, and revitalization efforts are ongoing to ensure these languages survive for future generations.

pwn: aza kemacalisian i Taiwan sedjelj a:
a kinavadavadayan noa aico a kemacalisian, savid to makamaza i mareka ljacadja ta qinaljan katoa i ljaviljaving ta ljavek i Taiwan.
english: These languages are spread across various regions in Taiwan, with some communities residing in remote mountainous areas, while others are found along the coast.
A Legacy of Suppression and Revitalization

pwn: itoa cinalivatan a likisi, aza kai noa kacalisian, ayatoa maljian a paljavak a mareka siho.
english: Throughout history, the use of Formosan languages has been suppressed under different colonial regimes.

pwn: tiamadjo nasema picol a lemivo katoa maselapai, parotoa aico a pinenetjan pinaka amin a ita a kai a ciniokokoan kemasi 1949 patje 1987 a caviljan. avansika dikinay anga macekaw toa aico a kemacalisian tazoa. sika tjadjaljaw a maqolip anga za kai, otaota namasan pazangal to pazorong ta kai itoa maqacovocovong.
english: he most striking example occurred during the Mandarin-only policy from 1949 to 1987, which enforced Mandarin Chinese as the sole official language, significantly impacting the transmission of Formosan languages to younger generations.

pwn: sitocoan, patagilj a tja seqetjen a kemacalisian a sengsengan, ayatoa napaposaladj na siho katoa papopicol pasatoa mareka saliman noa sikataqaljan.
english: In recent years, there has been a resurgence of interest in revitalizing these languages, driven by government initiatives and grassroots efforts.

pwn: avansika izoa mareka sengsengan pakatoa kai a paljazoa pitoa sinopoan i kakitoloan, a pitoa sisekingan, a pitoa tilibi katoa seman kamokoan.
english: This includes language education in schools, proficiency exams, immersion programs, and media broadcasting in Indigenous languages.

pwn: otaota aza kinateveteveljan noa qineponepoan toa valjicoq ta sipapilazekan a cemokicok toa kai noa kacalisian katoa zoma a kinateveteveljan namasan pazangal itoa aico a sengsengan.
english: The Indigenous Languages Research and Development Foundation and various local organizations play a vital role in these efforts.

pwn: djavadjavay a mapoljat imaza itoa wanglo i FormosanBank, a pinenetjan mavan a kidjomak toa milimilingan a sengsengan. izoanan a nia sinivarong to semeqetj sa paljazoa toa tja kai se kacalisian i Taiwan.
english: Welcome to FormosanBank, a large-scale data-driven project dedicated to the preservation and revitalization of the Indigenous Formosan languages of Taiwan.

pwn: aico a mareka kinakaian namasan pazangal aravac toco itoa pinenetj a kai na senatao, ljakoa toco na secevong toa gemagalj, aza masanitalj izoa ori maqolip a gemagaljan a monday paro tjamapoljo anga sikataqaljan a saigo a qivo.
english: These languages, which form a significant part of the Austronesian language family, are endangered, with some facing the risk of extinction.

pwn: avansika aza tja sengsengan imaza mavan a lemingdjelj toa kikai sa maqati a kemeljang to namakoda a macekaw ca nia vinecikan, no tjaivililj, teveljeng a kinkiw, patolo katoa papigacal a saliman.
english: Our mission is to create a comprehensive, machine-readable corpus of these languages to support linguistic research, language education, and revitalization efforts.

pwn: imaza itoa FormosanBank, maqati son a kemin toa pakata aico a qinepo kata pinalimasodj a poloq saka onem a kemacalisian a vecik a pinakeljang.
english: Here, you'll find a description of the corpus collected and processed across the 16 official Formosan languages, which includes over 8 million tokens and over 730 hours of audio across the languages (detailed breakdown can be found here).

english: You can also access the github with all the work and data related to FormosanBank here and the Drive folder with all the audio files from here.

english: The large-scale nature of FormosanBank would not have been possible without the collaborative efforts of numerous individuals and organizations.
